Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I wince at the pins and needles throbbing in my hand, thinking about how I'm gonna borrow my cousin and her law degree and sue that damn bitch. Engineering might make me just enough to get by beyond the mortgage, but there's no way in hell I'm paying for medical care. I'll take an Uber to the hospital before I call an ambulance.

 Cursing under my breath makes it easier to bear. I tear the sleeve off my muddy, bloodstained shirt so I can try to wrap it up, all while I try to remember the content of my middle school health class.

 It's the first time I'm able to look around and take in my surroundings. The sky is overcast and pitch-dark, with none of Denver's light pollution obscuring the stars. A great body of water spans before me, which is puzzling: if I left the adjoining unit from the front, shouldn't Emerald Lake be a couple blocks away?

 My housing development is devoid of streetlights by design, but when I squint to see the lights that illuminate the road, they flicker. The roads are dirty. And as I grasp the fabric of my tattered shirt as tightly as I can, plotting a large, crimson cardioid, I wonder how the HOA could ever let things get this bad with how much they scalp me every month.

 A couple strangers approach. They hasten their walk when they find I'm on my knees: two of them far larger than I am, but all four of them far more built. They're carrying swords and wearing armor.

 I don't know whether to laugh or to cry.

 Hiding behind them is a furry, watching nervously. I'm distracted by how perfect their fursuit is: her eyes move away when I try to meet them, flicking the tail with some kind of servo or something.

 "What is going on in this suburb? Early Halloween? Did y'all leave a D&D session? I thought it was all old people here," I say.

 "Old people? This is the Millitary District," one of them says, 'casting fire' in their palm to give us some light. I'm impressed at how well they sell it.

 The darker-skinned bald one bends down to look at my palm, still taller than my crouch at half his height. "You have got a good slice there. What happened?"

 "Was it Chymaerans?" The other lunk says.

 The others look at him disapprovingly.

 "Enough of the Chymaeran talk," says a woman with short, dirty blond hair. "I've got the training. I can heal him."

 "As in a med-kit?" I ask. "Some peroxide and a bandage?"

 "No," She says, snarkily. "Essence."

 "What is that?" I expect it's an off-brand painkiller or holistic herbs, nothing better than a Band-Aid.

 She says, "Look — do you want my help or not?"

 "Sure," I say. She groans in annoyance before taking my palm between her hands. "Where's the Neighborhood Patrol? I thought the cops were supposed to be out since those kids went tagging at the pool," I say.

 "What in Khiras' name are you on about?" The African-American one asks. He looks me up and down. "You're rather odd. Are you sure you're from here? What's your name, anyway?"

 "Name? He who asks should give their name first," I say. These weeaboos might get a kick from an anime reference if they're gonna pretend-heal me with their Etsy light gloves.

 "My name is Ryder Zebal. This is Jullian, Oria, Pax, and Caeda," he says.

 Might as well befriend the neighbors. "I'm Cody. Cody Dunsmore, and I just moved here." I realize I don't have a hand to shake: my left one is being healed with what feels like glove-warmers and LEDs.

 "Too strange for a Chymaeran," the lunk called Pax says.

 "How about your papers?" Ryder asks.

 "Uh ... alright." The word 'papers' is kinda weird, but I play along with their improv, in case they live close and I'll have to see them again.

 I reach into my back pocket with my right hand, but my wallet isn't there. I must have left it on the counter after I tipped the delivery guy.

 "Hold on a sec," I say.

 They reach for their swords though I can only reach one hand myself, all while Oriya is still 'working her magic.'

 I retrieve my phone from my pocket. They stare as if it were some kind of monolith. I light the screen with a tap then swipe up to turn on the flashlight.

 Click.

 They instantly dive backwards, frightened when the blinding flash illuminates the streets brighter than the flickering lamps.

 "Good thing I downloaded the MyColorado App recently, in case the cops stop me and I forgot my license. Let's see here . . ." I swipe down to type M-Y-C in the search bar, and then tap the first result.

 They're still petrified, standing there with their swords drawn.

 "Very funny. You guys are great at improv," I say. "See? Right here. Class C. I can drive, officer." I hold the bright screen towards Ryder. He draws closer, entranced by the display.

 "What kind of magic is this? Are you some kind of mage? An inventor in the Royal Court of Science? Or are you a Mask? Of the Gods?"

 "I'm just an engineer," I tell them. "Hardly one at that."

 "An inventor, then," Jullian says.

 I look to the full-on furry catgirl. She's hypnotized as if I shined a laser in front of her.

 "Well, I should get going," I tell them, feeling light-headed. "I've got to get home and bandage this for real. It's going to—" I flex my hand. It feels like nothing. I turn the flashlight from the roadway, looking down at my palm.

 I turn to Oriya. "How in God's name did you do that? Did you glue it?"

 "No, idiot. You're Human, aren't you? Don't you have the powers of fire and life?"

 "No?" I say.

 "Well, get on home," Oriya says. The others ramble to themselves about the strangeness of what just happened. Oriya reaches to hug Jullian's arm, and he uncomfortably obliges. I wait until the four of them disappear into the shadows.

 I try the handle of the door.

 It's locked.

 I run around the back, onto a cobblestone street. Counting as many houses over as it took to turn the corner, I try the window.

 It's open.

 I flex my left hand, still not feeling any anguish, pressing my ear to the window to try and discern where the girl is. I spend minutes listening to silence, until I hear Miguel's scream on the other side.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I'm mystified when I cross the threshold of the door. The room is dark, and though I can't make out the meager spread of items, I can sense how strange the shapes in this room are: so smooth and straight, as if they were cut by divine hands. When I find a glint in the artifacts on the shelves and walls—even the shelves themselves—I marvel at how much metal must have been wasted to produce all these things. He must be rich if he can waste money like this: maybe he's so rich that he bribed the Guard to let him live here, in a prime spot looking across the water.

 Does he actually live next door? Did I really mistake this as a closet? My metal boots clatter like hooves against the reflective wood floor, and I trace my finger along the polished granite table, trying to imagine how the resources got here.

 A crunch startles me. On the floor are what looks like hand-painted ration cans, but they're all crushed and ruined.

 I'm startled again when I hear snoring in the corner, and I find another odd stranger. A friend? A lover? Maybe a visitor past curfew? My feet sink into the carpet when I approach him, wondering again how the scruffy noble could ever afford such luxurious flooring.

 The entire room stinks of man, but this one smells especially bad. He mumbles in a drunken stupor before he awakes, blinking his eyes like a toad.

 "Uh . . . hey."

 "Hello," I say, wishing I had not ditched the dagger.

 He asks, "And you are?"

 "Katiya. Katiya Breakey-Hilde," I say.

 "Carajo. My homie's got no chill if he's bringing girls like you over while I'm here. Must be desperate since he's got no hose."

 "A hose? Why would you—" I begin to ask, but he cuts me off.

 "I think he's upstairs," he tells me, squinting his eyes, and then some semblance of recognition crosses his face. "Wait a minute — you must be from that fantasy escort service down in Denver, what was it called, uh . . . Call To Adventure, or something like that?"

 "I only do escort missions through the Royal Guard," I say.

 "Hah. Good one," he says.

 "It is good," I say.

 "Good." He clicks his tongue. "Figures. My boy Cody could never score a baddie like you."

 "Cody," I say.

 "Yep."

 An odd name.

 "And I'm Miguel."

 Another odd name.

 He says, "But he's a real one, let me tell you. My friend is the best dude you'll ever meet. I love that guy. You might be here for just a night — and, look, I know the whole thing about falling in love with a call girl — but give him a chance, huh? Even if it's just a booty call thing," he says.

 His hand grazes the table, accidentally casting some black, slender object on the floor. It bounces twice before colliding with something else.

 I hear a click, and then behind me, a flash of colorful light envelops the room. I gasp when I turn to look, and my heart jumps into my throat.

 Behind the bright window, a mother and daughter are screaming at each other. It gives me such a start that I collapse into the couch. The woman is screaming, the daughter is screaming, I'm screaming, and the man is shouting, trying to free himself from my armor.

 I spew a string of apologies as the woman in the window says something about wanting her body back, just as all I want is to go home. Too panicked to realize that the best direction is from whence I came, I sprint for the door as the other guy curses, grasping his leg.

 I'll just go around like Cody. We'll trade places.

 Just like my intruder, I trip backwards out the door, scraping the edges of the cement with my plate armor as I slide down the sculpted stairs, coming directly to a stop beneath a blinding torchlight. I scramble to my feet to try and run, but everything is so bright and unfamiliar that I fall to my knees.

 The sky is cloudless, but I can't find a single star. Lake Garrison is nowhere to be found; instead of the distant lights of my hometown of Hillfar, a pattern of white-and-red dotted lights slide past each other on a hill, somewhere far beyond the eaves of two houses on the other side of the road.

 Something loud is approaching. I try to curl into a ball to protect myself, but the armor stiffens me too much. A massive automobile tears past, lighting the entire street with headlamps lodged in the front, unlike anything I've ever seen. It sounds like they have an entire orchestra in there behind the glass, but the deafening music fades . . . only to be replaced by two more loud metal chariots that shake the ground.

 I'm quivering as I lay there in the grass, wondering where the garden is; why the lake isn't directly across from me; why stars shifted in the sky so swiftly.

 An old woman walks on the side of the street, and I consider she's a lamplighter until I see her holding a leash. She notices me crumpled in the grass on the verge of tears.

 "Are you alright, sweetheart?" She asks.

 "No," I cry.

 Her familiar crosses the grass, nuzzling me with its wet nose before it licks my face.

 "Oh, that's Doby. She's real friendly with all the young'uns living around here — do you mind dogs? Or are you more of a cat person?"

 "I'm a human person. A living human—"

 "—I swear to the good Lord in heaven: if this neighborhood is turning into one of those 'college' towns the Facebook talks about, with all these young'uns in their new houses playing trapping music, I'm going to lose it!"

 I haven't the time to protest when I hear a hissing noise, and it sounds like the elder is conjuring a serpent. Before I can react, I feel a cloudless rain, followed by a direct blast of water to my face, saturating the clothes beneath my armor in seconds.

 "Why? Why do you torment me?" I plead, my tears now inseparable from the water soaking me down to my underwear.

 "I didn't set the timer on those sprinklers," she says, and then adds, "damn beatnik."

 As I kneel in the muddy grass, sullying my new pants, I watch as the cantankerous woman retreats, dragging the mutt alongside her. A single, white moon hangs in the sky. Blinking red and white flashes somewhere even higher, casting smoke in a faint line, leaving the sound of a crackle as it slices the sky. I never knew the sky could be torn.

 With my mind petrified, locking my muscles, resigning me to soak in the jets of water, my body decides for me, urging me back inside to pass Cody's cursing companion.

 All I want is to return to the comfort of Fosroth where the world is uncomplicated. I want a cup of tea and a book beside the fire as I warm my bones. I will never bear witness to this horrifying illusion again.

 I ignore his companion's threat to take shots, though he holds a bottle instead of a gun, — asking if his friend paid for any more guards to defend this house. But as I stumble towards the closet, squeaking my saturated boots with each step, all I find is another figure, standing there at the back of the closet.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I throw open the window, dragging myself over the sill and depositing myself on the floor. My shoulder aches where her scalding hands burned me. I twist my body to get my feet beneath me, and manage to stand in front of the door.

 I level the lacrosse stick after I lift it off the floor, tearing off the rubber end cap, flipping it around so the basket faces me. And surely enough, like a reflection in the mirror, I find the female knight standing there on the other side.

 We pause there for a couple seconds. There's a panic still deep inside her eyes. I stagger my footing with my hands together on the stick, ready to body her with a cross-check, waiting for her to make the first move since I'm on the defensive.

 "En garde," I say.

 And then she charges me.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I wager my strength and power over his defenses. The inebriated man called Cody holds the odd, metallic broomstick with his hands together in the center — a technique I've never seen before — and calls out a phrase I can only decipher as a challenge.

 If it's a sword fight he wants, I know I can make it to the greatsword leaning against the wall, because if this Auvryan cross-blood wants to wreak havoc on my home life with his illusions, sullying the most sacred place I have to replenish myself and find respite, then I have no other choice.

 He must be destroyed.

 Cody drags his left foot behind him, bending his knees, leaning his body in a forward squat as if that can stop me. Surely this assassin is an Auvryan, and likely some kind of mercenary: their people are masters with pole weapons. But I doubt his technique is greater than the strength of a full-blooded Human flooded with Essence.

 I charge with my armored left shoulder, allowing the Essence to flow into my legs, flooding my muscles with such power that every step deflects the floorboards. I close the distance faster than he expects, but he remains steadfast, standing there with the metal broom raised to chest height, hinging his arms to receive the full force of my momentum.

 It's when I'm three steps from deliverance that he bends to get under me — but my muscle memory is far faster. I lower myself further than he can, sliding beneath the pole, driving my metallic shoulder into his chest and blasting him in the air.

 He lets out a rasping wheeze when his ribs bend towards his lungs. He's lucky that nothing inside him breaks: maybe it's the alcohol on his breath that hints that his muscles are loose, and that he's feeling a little braver than he might be otherwise. Cody crashes against my wall, leaving a sizable divot in the aged wallpaper, and before the ground reclaims him, I manage to snag the greatsword with my left hand, dragging it across the floor to assume a defensive stance.

 Somehow, he still manages to death-grip the broom between his hands, coughing and gasping for air as he lifts himself to his feet, overflowing with adrenaline and rage that radiate in his reddening face.

 I realize I left him an opening to escape. I expect him to cower, retreating to his conjured illusion to never return. But he flips the broom end of the stick to face him, exposing a sharp, hollow edge.

 His hapless courage is admirable. Maybe I would have fallen for him if this were training, and we were on the same side of the war.

 Cody coughs. "You couldn't just let me go, could you?"

 "I need to be sure you can't ever ruin my peace again."

 He takes several labored breaths, clutching his chest, swinging the sharp end of the broom in several circles. "So you're trying to kill me, then?"

 "It's not my fault that you broke in."

 "I was trying to tell you that the door was open. What the hell kind of neighbor are you?"

 "You're not strong enough to be my neighbor," I tell him.

 The ceiling has just enough clearance to swing the greatsword in a vertical slash. I expect this cumbersome move to give him enough of a start to really escape this time, but he still refuses, standing there with the stick between his hands.

 The sword traces a faint line in the wooden ceiling before gravity does the rest of the work. It clashes with the broom — and I fully expect it to break through — but all my greatsword does is well a deep notch in the hexagonal shaft.

 He mutters something about the material, cursing about how this broom is personal to him, but I know very little of the Auvrya or their traditions. My blade releases sparks when I try to pull it back, grinding against the notch, but the further I pull, the higher the blade climbs.

 I hear the screech of metal-on-metal, and it seems it's his turn to close the distance. He grinds the pole against the sharp edge, driving the sword higher and higher until it falls behind my hands. I'm left defenseless, and he jabs the plastic head of the stick against my breastplate, driving me to the floor.

Manuscript.Label: Paragate
Manuscript.Synopsis: Katiya struggles to shut out the intruder.
Manuscript.Summary:
> Katiya finishes the fight and the two separate.
> Katiya calms her panic, and finds Cody's iPod.
> Katiya uncomfortably goes to work with Jullian and others. Refuses scouting.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
Whatever that thing is, it isn't a broom.

 My mind races, but I still manage to remember the bloody dagger in the sink.

 I roll behind the kitchen island as he brandishes the head of the stick against a wooden bowl on the counter, casting a whole slew of produce against the ground.

 I lift myself by the counter's edge to dig my hand into the sink, feeling for the hilt of the dagger.

 "Your fight is with me, not the damn house!" I say.

 He bends down to scoop up one of the apples with the stick, taking it into the basket. I level the dagger at him, taking a butcher's knife in my other hand, completely unsure of what he's going to do next.

 His hands shift to the sharp end of the stick, leaving the basket at a certain length behind him.

 Then he whips it down as hard as he can.

 The apple whizzes past my head, exploding against the stone wall, casting chunks of its sugary flesh and skin into my hair.

 "I should have practiced since the club team sophomore year," he says, slurring his words. "Next one's going corner-pocket in your damn eye socket."

 "Not if I end you first," I say.

 The assassin scoops up an orange with a single flick of his wrist. I ready the knife block. He launches a second one, but I'm quick enough to slice it with my dagger before it blasts me in the forehead.

 My eyes burn with the citrus, and when I think he's reeling to throw something harder — like a pear or another apple — squinting as I wipe the juice with my dagger hand, I use my unpracticed off hand to flick the kitchen knife through the air.

 It spins several times before embedding itself into the wall behind him. He freezes. I set the dagger on the counter, taking three more kitchen knives into my left hand, certain that I can hit dead-center now that my dominant hand is free.

 I whip a second one, letting the Essence tension the fibers of my muscles, launching the paring knife faster than an arrow.

 But he's already pitching up the overturned kitchen table.

 The tablecloth hovers to the floor like melting ectoplasm before the paring knife pins it to the table. Cody lets out a yelp in fear, surely unhurt since the blade is far shallower than the thick mahogany.

 I decide to upgrade to a carving knife, withdrawing all five inches from the block. I judge its balance.

 He peeks from behind the table, and I whip the carving knife where I expect his chest to be, thinking it's his body that braces the table upright.

 But he bends back.

 It stabs through almost up to the handle.

 "Holy hell," he exclaims.

 I wind up to throw another as he pulls the small knife from the wallpaper, then throw it. The boring knife spins through the air, nearly pinning his hand to the wall. He catches me off guard when he emerges from the side of the table. I reach for another culinary weapon, but I realize my offhand is out of blades.

 The oddly-dressed assassin flips the blade to set the sharp edge between his fingers, his eyes dark and piercing as he raises his elbow and lifts the knife behind his head. The panic seizes my heart: this assassin's skilled enough to engage a vetted Royal Guard when he's two sheets to the wind. I'm certain a knife will soon be in my chest, and all I can do is ready myself for the deliverance of cold steel.

 And then he throws it.

 I expect it to fly so fast that I can't catch a glimpse of its glistening edge before it embeds itself between my breastplate. I expect my consciousness to end, to wash in the next fated moment upon the Reservoir of Souls.

 But I can see it.

 And it's not coming at me.

 It flies so far to the right that I wonder if he's aiming at something else. The paring knife spins horizontally through the air, twirling and spinning with such disarray that it only makes it halfway to the kitchen before it clatters against the floor.

 "Damn it!" he says.

 The laugh escapes before my hands cover my mouth. I can't even stop the loud snort. His face is crestfallen, even more hurt than the time I rammed him.

 "You should stick with that strange basket-stick of yours," I tell him.

 Cody's voice wavers. "It's called a lacrosse stick," he says, blushing hard, peeking over the edge with his glasses as he struggles to withdraw the carving knife from the other side.

 I thought he was an Auvryan mind-flayer — a mythical master of mental manipulation, maybe commissioned by the Chymaera. But he's no warrior. Just a stupidly-brave commoner that's overconfident in his skills. And a complete idiot.

 I can't stop laughing.

 "What are you, some kind of combat janitor? Do you sweep floors with that thing?"

 His face reddens further, whether it's the booze, his humiliation, or both. I feel the relief wash over me as the Essence retreats from my circuits.

 "Gods above, for a second I thought you were an actual threat," I say.

 "Who says I'm not?" He scoops a tomato into the 'cross stick', poised to whip another one.

 "Just . . . stop," I tell him. "I'm not going to kill a civilian."

 "Maybe you should reconsider," he says.

 "Consider this."

 I raise my hands and cast a controlled plume of flames. He flinches when they stop only inches from his face, dropping something hard and small from his pocket. He has to steady himself with the odd weapon as he stumbles towards the closet.

 "Really, Cody. Do you even understand our training? How much Essence a Royal Guard is conditioned with? How much mead does it take to get this kind of courage? I could snap your bones with my hands!"

 "I'm your neighbor. I live right next door . . . through there," he says, lifting a bare arm exposed by his scalded shirt to point towards the closet.

 "Why are you living in the military district?"

 "I live in Hearthland Ridge," he insists. "The military base is down in Cheyenne, or maybe Fort Carson."

 "This is Gaffesend," I tell him.

 "No, this is Colorado. The United States," he says.

 "Nothing is united in all of Fosroth. You can't be stupid enough to be a tourist at the war front!" I say.

 "The war is overseas. It's fought with drones and bombs."

 "It's waged with swords and rifles!"

 I approach him until I can smell the booze on his breath. My eyes flutter between his exposed chest and his arms, a little impressed at his definition when he obviously has no Essence. I catch him glimpsing at my bare thighs that once straddled him, and then to my breastplate, before returning my glare and slowly backing up towards the closet.

 But his heels catch on the threshold.

 He falls through the portal, unable to steady himself with his weapon before he crashes to the ground on the other side. I take one more glance at the horrors of that incomprehensible world: all its glistening, colored lights like Essenced lightning bugs. The fear forestalls me from passing that threshold ever again, so I stand there: watching; waiting; listening to the faintness of his breath; until I'm certain his intemperance will keep him there.

 But the fear of that other world overpowers my penchant for patience. I slam the door behind him, certain I'll never have to face that stranger again.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I dig my heels into the space between the floorboards, catching my breath as I drive my back against the closet door. My nails tension against the pad of my palm, leaving crescents in my flesh as the blood drains from my fingertips.

 My heart can only take so much in a day. I thought the enemy could only strike when my presence was voluntary; when I patrol the borders of Gaffesend by my own volition. And it only took a day for this peaceful haven to be violated by a stranger.

 I can't keep sitting here. The curse will catch me if I don't get up: the white feeling that tensions my hands and sets my body in full static. The shorter the time between those moments of frantic stillness, the easier it slides into that incontrovertible state of shock. It's addiction without a pleasure to be addicted to, and the more often that white feeling haunts me, the stronger it gets — so I'm glad when I find my effects are still scattered across the floor. A mess to clean is the second-best thing to distract me right now: the first is going to the bar, but after my episode, I'd rather not be seen in public.

 I let my mind flow with visions of how I can transform this space into a place of respite, rather than feeling like an ephemeral halfway-house between training and the front lines. The mind is a vessel that can only hold so much at a time, so I drink to the the purity of those beautiful thoughts, driving down the opacity of fear's murky brine. The pale white feeling fades as the light begins to shine through, reaching my furthest depths.

 When my hands stave off the static, I gather the courage to seal that passageway forever.

 I let the Essence flood my circuits with enough heat to melt the handle of the closet door to the deadbolt, ensuring it's locked forever. Then I drag an empty bookcase across the floor to cover it. It irritates me that it's slightly spaced from the wall due to the protrusion of the melted handle, so I melt the rest of it, turning the balled handle into a flat plate pressed against the profile of the wooden door, deciding it's good enough to try to forget.

 I lack the Auvryan magic of mind, but I hypnotize myself anyway.

 The bookcase has always been here.

 Next, I purge anything that reminds me of him.

 I wipe his blood from the dagger. I return the fruit scattered across the floor into the bowl. I pull the kitchen knives from the overturned table and reset the tablecloth the other way around, covering the gaping holes in the wood. Finding the evidence is still in the fabric, I sew the clean cuts in the tablecloth closed with thread from my sewing kit. I mop and dab all the puddles and smudges. This leads to finding places for the hundred pounds of my unpacked personal items, placing them anywhere but the closet I should have forgotten, which leads to re-orienting all the decorations and furniture and bookshelf to make the space my own, which leads to dusting every surface I can find. Before long, I find my exasperated body sprawled across the kitchen's area rug, drugged by the excitement of exertion, staring at the cross-beams of the low wooden ceiling with a slight smile on my face.

 I hoped so dearly that this distraction would let me forget.

 But even still, I find the urge to reconcile that impossibility.

 I need to keep moving. I need to find something to fix when I can't leave this house. Since I can't patch the dent in the wall, I decide to look harder for any dust that might coalesce beneath the cabinets. I roll over to find the duster did its job well, but there's something else tucked under there.

 It's a strange, slender, rectangular object beneath the cutout of the kitchen cabinet. Like all the other things in his realm, it's perfectly smooth and square — but I can tell it's been worn from years and years of continuous use. It would look like an ingot if it wasn't so flat: hardly enough for a blacksmith to smelt it into anything. When I turn the heavy block in my hands, I find that I'm able to read the foreign words on the back, etched in white beneath an image of a bitten fruit:

LOVE YOU JACKIE D

FROM CODY 2010

MERRY CHRISTMAS

160 GB

 A set of long, slender wires snake from the bottom of it, ending with white buds that look like they could grow into flowers. Does it work with electricity? Because it's certainly not plugged in to anything.

 A light tug pulls out the buds by their roots. I panic for a second until I realize I'll never have to return this thing to him.

 When I jam the buds' metal root back into the hole, the dark square on the front turns on, glowing with an impossible, radiant white, labeled with options in black.

 It takes me a while to figure it out, but when my finger glides on the circle, the little window changes. I settle the black bar on PICTURES, expecting a photograph to dispense from the tiny slot in the bottom.

 I press the center button.

 But instead, the window shows a gateway to an entirely different world. It reminds me of the moving projections that I heard were in the theatre rooms of the capital, though this one is so impossibly small — and there's not a creature in existence that could roll the image from inside. It reminds me of the screaming woman behind the window on the stranger's wall.

 There's so many tiny squares of color that make this picture, but it's still hard to make out. Two people sit at a table in a stone-walled room lit by a very bright lamp. One is small: just a boy, and the other is older, wearing some kind of green-and-brown uniform — sharp enough in dress that I figure he's a warrior.

 All I can tell is that they care for each other: sitting together building something metallic and square with wires hanging off of it. And they have this same device there, sharing the white buds between their ears.

 I try the same with the round white shapes, but nothing happens. I click another button on the side. The screen goes black, reflecting my eyes on its worn, yet polished surface, and when I realize how time has passed, I look up at the hands of the clock.

 Dear Gods above: a whole hour has passed. If I don't sleep now, dusk will overtake any chance of rest.

 I run upstairs with the device in my hand, leaving the square pod and its tangled wires as the first decoration on my nightstand. My body is exhausted from all the fear, and I don't have to even draw the covers to find myself in slumber. I just collapse onto the bed, retreating into a deep sleep where the smoke of the cabin across the lake never reaches me.

 My mind remembers the contours of Cody's body beneath the tattered shirt. I can't escape the thought in my dreams, no matter how much physical or mental furniture I pile against the sealed door.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I wake to a rapping on my door, but it's not the rhythm of the personal knocker. When I dip my head out the window, I find Bertram standing on the top step.

 "You're up early," I say. I slept in my plainclothes, so I don't have to hide behind the curtain. " I don't even think the knocker is awake yet."

 He tilts his head up at me. "Sorry to wake you. I figure we might want to get started early if we're returning those quest forms."

 Sure. I'll be out in a minute," I tell him, rushing through a minimal routine, ensuring I look "royal" enough for the Royal Guard.

 When I descend the stairs into the immaculate foyer, the smell of bread confirms it's going to be another quick morning without cracking a can of rations. I pinch twenty Kine from my coin purse and pass it out the back window.

 Another voice rises from the front of the flat. And then another one. And after I dress myself in light armor for another day of chores, I throw open the door to find two others have joined us.

 Jullian stands behind Bertram with Oriya, and he offers an explanation I never asked for. "She wanted to join us on the walk over, she asked me last night. We're right next to each other, anyways."

 "Oh," I tell him.

 Oriya turns her head.

 "I'm surprised you never stopped by to check on me," I tell him.

 "We were out late, past midnight, looking at only a few hours of slumber. I didn't want to wake you since you were sick, I figured you were long asleep," he says.

 "Sure," I tell him.

 But you certainly could have made it a lot better.

 Jullian offers his hand. I tension my fingers between his, looking for a squeeze of reassurance.

 He returns one.

 "I really could have used you last night," I tell him. You're never comfortable with the concept of staying.

 "I just knew that if I was there, neither one of us would have slept at all," he says, returning a smile. "And you were feeling ill, so you needed all the rest you could get."

 "I guess." I turn my head to watch in amusement as Oriya and Bertram struggle to overcome the most basic conversational hurdle.

 "But I really wish you were there last night," Jullian says. "There was hardly anything for us to do. From what all the senior guards say, it seems like junior scouting missions carry light expectations. If that's as bad as it gets, then this will be a whole lot easier than all the training that led up to it."

 "That's nice," I tell him.

 "And we all got to know each other a lot better than any other night out," Oriya says.

 "Did you?" I ask.

 "Yeah," Oriya says. "You and Bertram should join us next time!"

 "Sure," I say, tensioning my fingers further against Jullian's hand.

 Oriya decides to continue. "I've talked to Jullian a lot, but not you, Katiya," she says.

 I say, "I guess our paths never really crossed. Even in field training."

 Oriya looks at my boyfriend. "Tell me, how is it that you two met?"

 I open my mouth to answer, but I hesitate, starving for a small sliver of reassurance. I want to know that he remembers.

 "Why don't you tell her, Jullian?" I ask. I think he'll stammer for a second, but he's quick, so much that it almost sounds rehearsed.

 "Sure. It was because we had one thing in common," Jullian says.

 "And what's that?" Oriya asks.

 "We were both dirt poor."

 Oriya narrows her brows. "Really? I never would have guessed."

 "It's true," I say. "When my brother Erik was sent to Gaffesend, and I was in the last year of training, I had to take up Erik's share of responsibilities. Our mother was busy on the looms in the factory." I turn to Jullian, prodding further. "And the day we met?"

 "Yeah — we were taking night classes because we both worked during the day. It was the second-to-last semester, late one night when I was returning from an exam. I had to take my brother to the academy because I was watching him, and as we're walking home, he sees this beautiful girl passing us."

 "How old was your brother?" Oriya asks.

 "He was eight," Jullian says. "Anyways, I must have been ranting to him about how little time I have for anything, because, get this — he walks straight up to her, tugs on her shirt, and says, 'Hey lady: my brother is lonely and sad: can you fix him?'"

 "Really?" Oriya turns to me. "And that worked on you?"

 "I guess so," I say. "I have little half-siblings, too, so I guess I have a soft spot for that impudence. There wasn't really anyone there for me at the time, and with so much coming after graduation, I was willing to give him a chance." I only realize what I implied when I look to Bertram.

 Jullian says, "I was a loner. I thought I wasn't worthy, that I was a loser, that nothing would ever work out for me. But Katiya blessed me with something I'd never felt before. And sometimes I'm still not sure I deserve it." I think he intends it as a joke, but there's just enough substance that it makes the others feel uncomfortable.

 It makes me feel so warm when I remember how great he was with my two half-siblings. How he'd wait for me every night after classes, and we'd stay up until the morning just talking about our lives, until a couple months passed and we were brave enough to explore something else in each other.

 But he almost looks sad sharing these memories: holding the same expression on his face I found when we drew closer to graduation, when after challenging each other for months and months to be at our best, we climbed the ranks high enough to be withheld from direct service. It was on the week-long trip to Gaffesend that I saw the biggest change. Before that, he was right on the threshold of opening up, but after a week with his first group of guy friends, following them around to pubs in every layover town on the way to Gaffe, he started to feel colder, almost as distant as when I first met him and had to warm him up.

 I still find his eyes wander to other faces when we walk together, even right now, gaging reactions, forever looking for something he can't find. But with all the wonderful times we shared together, how far we opened up to each other, I'm certain that it's still there, regardless of how the conditions have changed.

 "We're still so young," he mutters, just between the two of us.

 "I know," I tell him. "How is that relevant?"

 He pauses, as if he meant to think it. "But my future is always with you."

 The familiar nervous tick rises where he scratches at his arms. I still wait to hear those three words. We were so close before it felt like graduation changed everything, and part of me wishes we started earlier.

 We approach the quest board outside the re-purposed adventurer's guild building, swarming with junior guards. We submit our forms from yesterday for a sign-off. I apologize to Bertram, though he insists he knows what I meant, and I offer for the two of us to take on a quest together.

 "I think we should do a scouting quest together," he says. "How about a close one?"

 Jullian overhears us as he talks with his friends. I can tell he's trying to mask that he's actively listening.

 "I'm not sure," I say. "I think we should do something close."

 "This is the chance to take that next step, you know. I know we can do it. You and me, together. Nothing's going to happen."

 "Not today," I say, "but next time. I assure you. I just don't think I'm ready yet."

 "Even during the day?" Bertram asks. I can feel his disappointment weigh on my self-image. "It's just the other bank. Please, no more potato harvesting: my nails need a damn rest."

 "Then scouting the city?" I ask.

 "But in the forest, you can actually sit down most of the time. Make camp and relax, as long as you're quiet enough to listen."

 "I'm sure, but—"

 He pauses, realizing how his insistence weighs on me. "No. No, it's fine," he says. "I'm wrong. I'm sorry to push you. We can—"

 "It's alright, Bertram. I'll take one of the domestic quests alone: you go ahead."

 "No, but . . . are you sure?"

 "I'm sure," I say, watching his bright blue eyes fill with hesitation, though I've known him long enough to tell when there's something he really wants. "Really. Go on, I'll catch up with you after."

 "O-okay, then," he says. "Maybe tomorrow, then?"

 "Sure," and then I add, "Maybe. Sure."

 The masses begin moving for the shoreline to catch a boat across the lake. Julian stops me as I turn with the few stragglers heading for the mainland.

 "I'd really like it if you'd come with us," he says. The group of guys and girls look impatient, beginning to suspect something's off about me.

 "It's alright. I'd rather do stuff closer to home," I tell him.

 "Okay," he says.

 "Okay?" I almost expected more of a fight, more of an effort towards persuasion, but he turns to join the receding group before I have a chance to protest. Oriya is the only one waiting for him.

 "I'll catch up with you later," he says.

 "Okay," I mutter. But he's already too far away to hear it. I look down at the quest sheet I tore from behind all the other postings, wondering where this shameful feeling of unease will deposit me today.

> Reed Broderick is hired despite weakening job security.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
Late Sunday morning, around 11:00, I awoke with my neck twisted against the closet door, my face saturated with drool, shirt missing, and a sticky note taped to my forehead with Miguel's handwriting that read "DRINK WATER." The pounding headache had mostly subsided: I must have slept it off, or drank loads of water the night before from how quickly I immediately had to sprint to the restroom. And after relieving myself, I found my phone on the counter with three unread texts:

Miguel Ruelas // 06:37

u gotta tell me whassup with that wack cosplay chick. neighbor? break-in? u invite rollplay hookers over when i was asleep?

Miguel Ruelas // 07:13

or shit maybe I dreamt it, doesnt explain the bruise on my leg unless something happened that i forgot

Miguel Ruelas // 07:14

anyways congrats bro on the house. lets catch up next week im off to church. cleaned up some of the mess. love u bro

 I looked around to find that the madman actually cleaned everything. The pillows were arranged on the couch, the beer cans sorted into the recycling bin outside, and even the counters looked like he gave them a clean wipe. I responded:

Cody Dunsmore // 11:12

Thanks for cleaning up dude, you didn't have to do that! Let's chill next weekend. Not much else to do when everyone moved away :/

 Feeling disgusting, I rushed upstairs to take a shower, getting off the sweat and stench of a failed all-nigher. My shower thoughts brought me back to that dream in another world: getting slashed by a crazy roleplayer and encountering strangers in some semi-modern renaissance world. I looked down at my left hand, as if the warm shower water wasn't enough to tell me whether or not the flesh parted like a bad haircut. But all I found was smooth skin.

 It must have been a shared dream, like Inception, because I still don't recall inviting anyone over: hell, I don't even know who to call. But as the scalding water relieves the pounding in my head, I find that all I can think of is the magical woman I fought in my dreams, how she straddled me, threw knives at me, and cleaved that heavy greatsword straight into the middle of my lacrosse stick.

 I dried myself off before a different kind of pleasure could emerge from those thoughts: I was more absorbed by the strangeness of that vivid and continuous dream. My curiosity led me to try opening the door to the closet, finding another door behind it that looked as if its handle were blasted with a blowtorch.

 I just assumed I'd forgotten there was no closet. Were these pre-builds originally intended for a hotel chain or something with the neighbor door? It didn't make sense at all, but I knew I wouldn't feel safe, and I was actively looking for any kind of excuse to make something stupid in my robotics workshop.

 After a drive-thru breakfast, I went to the home improvement store to get one of those school-shooter-stopping door stops: one level shy of something permanent like bolting the damn door in place. With a spare microcontroller, I hooked up a hall-effect sensor and a buzzer — a magnet sensor and a loud speaker, basically — to detect if that door was ever to move. By soldering the wires to the breadboard, along with some AA batteries, and using generous dollops of hot glue to stick it to the inside wall of the strange-looking door, I called it a day around 9:30 PM, returning to my bed for an early night of sleep so I could get up tomorrow, only to spend four hours doom-scrolling through the week's sordid politics.

 I consider all these details right now when I'm driving ten over the speed limit. It's not wondering if the notched cut in my lacrosse stick was from when Miguel and I were drunkenly tossing a tennis ball outside, nor is it my missing iPod Classic. It's how I could have possibly screwed myself over this bad.

 I set three alarms. Either my dumb ass shut them off in succession, I slept through them, or I did bad math in figuring out the absolute latest I could wake up, forgetting that I had to take a shower. Now I'm screaming down the highway, hating myself as I KNOW that I'm going to either make it right on time or a couple minutes too late.

 I skipped breakfast when that ulcerous, cantankerous feeling arrested my stomach, running the numbers over and over and over about how long it would take me to get there. Now I calculate every second as I pull into the last roadway snaking up into the canyon, taking tight turns that jostle my backpack against the back seat, nearly screeching my tires when I pull up to the front gate.

 Eight fifty-three on the dashboard.

 The gate guard waves me through. Apparently two years is long enough for him to remember my face. I clip the badge to my wrinkled work shirt and gather my bag when my Subaru fits in the last spot available, sneaking in the back door.

 Eight fifty-eight.

 I sneak in with the technicians finishing their first union-mandated break. The ones I worked with make fun of me for being lazy, calling me an "eighter-skater".

 Eight fifty-nine.

 I climb the stairs. The rows of cubes are empty, and the sinking feeling deepens. What room is the meeting in? Was it thirty minutes earlier? I'll have to guess since I didn't check mail or Teams.

 Nine o'clock.

 I try to calm my breathing or else I'll embarass myself further. Fuck, the door's shut. I open the door with a pad and paper in my other hand, meeting six sets of eyes as I retreat to the back, not a chair left for me to sit in.

 "Barely on time, Cody," Nav says. In the dark room, his face is only lit by the computer, and the window of emails is up on the projector.

 "I'm sorry. I—" don't add kindling to the fire by using an excuse: I find I'm mostly out after this many years.

 Navesh continues. "As I was saying. I swear to be transparent with all of you when it comes to this stuff. They monitor what they tell me, because they know I'll just regurgitate it back to all of you, because you deserve that honesty," he says.

 Our team looks on with a knot in their stomachs: to my left, the Robinson-Monroe lifers Wilford Sameshima, a mechanical, and Michael Leguziamo, an electrical. To my right, Kei Sakurajima tensions her nails against her slender arm as she watches me for my own reaction, and mid-rank electrical Scott Valdez buries his face in his notepad.

 "You all know the Aerospace Division was expecting the contract. Which means power cell assemblies to design, which means busy work making our existing models fit to their demands," Nav says.

 Kei types something into her open computer. My wrist vibrates when she hits the return key:

SAKURA_KEI 09:02:15:

I thought I had tenure?

 It's an inside joke from when we had several electives together, when a professor was fired right in front of us. She cracks a smile that she fights to hide, trying to lighten the tension just a little. The humor joins the emotions inside my chest like adding oil to water, and not much for words right now, I respond.

DUNSMO_COD 09:02:43:

Guess not.

 Scott interjects, "So when are we looking at here? For the . . . reduction of staff."

 Even the lifers are afraid, tenured with all their tribal knowledge. Wilbur says, "How many per group? I mean, we have a small team."

 Nav predicates his next words with a warning. "Now, I'm not sure about any of this because they refuse to tell it straight. We're looking at one to two people, maybe. And we're looking at just before Christmas."

 "Just in time to get gifts for my kids," I say, before realizing I've spoken.

 "You don't have kids," Kei says.

 A nervous chuckle circles the room. Nav looks relieved that I tried to ligthen things: it feels like the first time I've been really useful to this team in a month.

 "They're probably going to ask me to make a list again, just like I did three years ago, some of you willl remember that. They're going to force me to rank you. And I'm sure you all know generally where you stand." I feel him staring at me through the back of his head: he doesn't have to turn around.

 "A team of six is already pretty damn small," Mike says, mumbling into his folded hands. "We're probably the smallest in the company already."

 "Which might mean we're fine. But it's not just six of us anymore," Nav says. I can see the notification come across his computer: one of the executives is waiting to enter the meeting after it is over.

 "What do you mean?" I ask, feeling my heart skip a beat. If it's HR, that means the reaper is taking someone away.

 "It's seven now. We vetted him before we lost the contract," Navesh says.

 "Did he even interview?" Kei asks. "I don't think any of us were there to get to know them."

 The executive walks in: it's my boss' boss, dressed to the nines, probably lost since someone like him would never even bother to step into a wing of the company like ours. Behind him is a dark-haired, clean-cut guy dressed like any of us used to: slacks, a belt, and a tucked-in collared shirt. Feels like we should stand at attention for such seniority, but I'm already up. The new recruit isn't nervous at all in introducing himself.

Manuscript.Label: Polishing Revision
Manuscript.Body:
"Nice to meet you all. I'm Reed Broderick," he says. The executive hands him two dozen donuts, and he puts them on the table. "I've heard this is how you make an impression."

 "You heard right," Kei says. The animals all reach their hands for the box, but I lean further against the wall.

 "So where are you from, Reed?" Michael asks, his mouth full of donut. "And how old are you? We've got a lot of young ones on this team now."

 "Twenty-eight. I graduated last year with a Mechanical degree, but I haven't found much of anywhere to work until now," he says.

 A year older than I am.

 The executive cuts in. "I can assure you that he's the best. You know his father, John: he used to work in Aerospace until he moved up."

 "So the legacy continues," Navesh says. "I remember your father! We worked together before they made me the captain of this ship."

 Reed exudes the rest of his confidence. "I know I didn't formally interview, but I'm really excited to be a part of this team. Let my work speak for me," he insists, walking around the table to join me in the back.

 Navesh squeezes words out under the executive's hopeful gaze: "Well, we certainly have fresh energy with all these young people here."

 Reed extends his hand, and I shake it. "Nice to meet you, bro," Reed says, and despite the added tension, I find myself relieved to make another possible friend.

 "Cody Dunsmore," I say. I'd compliment his firm handshake if it didn't make me feel like I was becoming my father.

 "And I'm Kei. Kei Sakurajima."

 She extends her hand as the others rise to introduce themselves like it's the start of a church service. The executive lifts himself from leaning against the door frame.

 "Then I guess I'll leave y'all to it," he says.

 As the others swarm our unexpected colleague, I try to remember my own first day here, but it was really like any other. It was five hours before IT could get my email working, and although Navesh was warm with his welcome, nobody stood from their cubes to do so much as introduce themselves. I had to bring my own 'new guy donuts' the next day to get the rest of the bean-counters and nerds to acknowledge my presence!

 We leave the room as soon as everyone gets their introduction. Nav looks like he wants to say something to me again about my timeliness, but is intercepted by Scott, and as we walk back, Reed takes a particular interest in Kei and I.

 "Designated seating, I was told," Reed says. He looks at the new edict from HR, a paper map atop his Bankers box of stuff. "Says I'm right next to you, Kei. Hope you're patient enough for all my questions."

 I curse the corporate gods of fate that put me in the empty row with Wilbur.

 "That shouldn't be a problem," Kei replies. "Cody's bothered me since day one, and he's still doing it."

 "How long have you both been here?" Reed asks.

 "Three years and some change," Kei says.

 "Are you also new?" Reed asks me.

 "No. I've been here for two years,"I tell him.

 "Oh." His eyes turn from my box on the map, which still reads SUPPORT ENGINEER, and I know I've been asking the same question.

 I feel a finger tap my shoulder after the others pass us. "Can I talk to you for a second?" Nav says.

 "Uh, yeah, sure," I tell him. My stomach drops further, realizing I have no idea if there's a bottom. We walk a couple steps to the row with vacant cubes.

 I try to take the fire from him by calling myself out first, stumbling over the first words that come to me. "I'm sorry I barely made it on time. Moving shouldn't be an excuse, and—"

 "I get it," he says. "But if you were any later, that would have been a reflection on me in front of my boss, and the kind of things that I allow here. I'm not safe here either. But, look. I don't know if you're just burned-out or something: you've been on the threshold of the next level for ages, and I get you're feeling restless, but . . ." He pauses because the next words are uncomfortable. "If I'm forced to make a list, I want you to be ready."

 "What do you mean?"

 "I mean that you're going to be near the bottom," he says, and then clarifies, "by rank."

 "Me and the newer . . . guy?" I ask, hushing my voice so no one can overhear me. Asking about seniority is totally my right, but I'm too damn nervous to bring it up.

 "You are, roughly."

 The rising feeling makes me ball my fists behind my back.

 I guess I only matter if I fucking know someone, I think.

 I hold back the strain in my eyes, and I find myself thinking that if my dream wasn't to work in that new building a little higher in the valley, and if the fears of that mortgage weren't so punishing, I'd be actively out looking for something else.

 Looking out the window at that building calms me down just enough to pedal a false face of humility. "I understand. I haven't been that great," I say.

 "No, I like you, Cody," he reassures me, but I don't feel it. "I don't pull the strings or drive the gears. I'm just a pinion between the executives and my team." An idler gear, only transferring the force it's given by the others.

 It takes a couple breaths before I can bring myself to respond. "I'll do better, then, whether it means something or not," I tell him.

 "Well, with all this idle time we're gonna have, we'll have a couple projects to improve stuff. Make stuff the customers don't know they want yet. For me, it was redesigning the battery enclosure that made me prove myself enough to move up. So maybe . . ."

 "It's a chance, you're saying."

 "But not a promise."

 I know that shit already, Nav, I think to myself, as I feel the whole path to my future rearranging itself in front of me. It takes all the strength I have to refuse to show it in my expression.

 A breath. And then another.

"I appreciate you telling me this," I manage, enough to get him to go away. As the first tear crests my eye, trying to suck it back into my tear duct, I take a deep breath and decide to take my break early.

Manuscript.Summary:
FOUR WEEK TIME SKIP
> Katiya continues taking domestic quests.The town hosts a wealthy family, but Chymaerans attack.
> Katiya tries to respond but freezes in fear, half-solving the problem. She races to Bertram.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Body:
There's no early breaks in all the domestic quests. It only took a couple days before I realized that sitting on the job was a bad image, unless you have a lunch pail in your hands. Just like any routine — whether it's a new cycle of combat training, classes, or a new job — the first three days are memorable because it's all so fresh. I thought taking different quests would make each day distinct from the last, but from the fourth day onward, it all became a blur of motion, forgotten at the end of each day by an exaspirated body and a tired mind.

 This is the first job on city watch that has me raking leaves on the side. Though the mountainside is still flushed with fading green, the eager leaves transform from yellow to red and deposit themselves early on the stone thoroughfares. From a raised vantage point at the southwestern hillside of Gaffesend, I abate the stress by drawing in the crisp mountain air, watching as the browning wild lashes of the southern grasslands are battered about by gale winds.

 Long in the distance, the grand lake reflects the shadowed mountain view, too far to make the crests of little waves. I watch as junior guards paddle back from their postings on the outer rim, wondering which of my friends are among them. But it's nice to know that at least I'm not alone.

 "Have you ever attached a broom handle to the end of it?" I ask. Her sharp eyes bounce between the rake and the tip of her tail.

 "I-I don't think that would work, it's not strong enough," Caeda says. I've gotten to know her a lot better: the shy pair well with the timid since they end up taking similar tasks. "When should we head down?"

 "Well there's certainly no shortage of leaves, the Verdalan Gods make sure of it. Maybe now, I guess," I tell her. "This was all supposed to be done before the royals came to town, as if miles of road could be effectively polished by five junior guards."

 "What does such a task even have to do with protecting?" Caeda mutters.

 "We're protecting . . . the . . . image, I guess, of the city. And next we'll be protecting the parade route."

 "Sometimes it feels like they're just trying to keep us busy with silly tasks," she says.

 "It's allowed me to get to know the locals really well, at least. They say they're glad we take the tasks that make a difference."

 "That's because you fawn for social interaction, it's quite marvelous to me how you're so full of energy all the time. But that's coming from someone who doesn't make friends unless they see them every day for about a month."

 "A month?" The math surprises me. But it sounds about right when I count all the days I've taken off. I walk with Oriya, Jullian, Berry, and Ryder every morning for five of them, to take new postings from the quest board and get to work. Every sixth or so, I persuade them to join me on a hike or go swimming in the hot springs. And every night is my chance to get out and socialize when I'm not taking night quests: having only scouted twice, I feel quite distant from the others.

 The loneliness carries into other areas, too. I've only seen Jullian five times since the start of this transition. Besides walking to work hand-in-hand, we've gotten together almost every day off to blow off some steam. I've only been able to convince him once to go on a date with me to the hot springs, and it was on my earnings. The other times he says he's too busy — though I always see him with his friends. It disappoints me when our acts of passion end as soon as he gets off: the only courtesy he seems to have is letting me get there first.

 We descend the hill as the northern scouts congregate in Gaffesend Square. The bell tolls midday: normally that would mean a break for rations, but our service is expected to run later, and nobody minds when it makes this a "two-quest-day."

 "I bet Bertram rues being sick when quest forms are this easy," I tell Cae. The slowness of this life almost makes me believe that Gaffe is as insular as the capital, capable of holding small events for royalty passing through the town. We're ordered to line up on the sides of the Main Street. It feels like a festival, the way all the street lamps are adorned with fresh flowers; the businesses shuttered for an hour; and the full population split between halves of the street. We stand in pattern between the onlookers and the empty road. The senior guards are busy on the city outskirts, demanding papers, and ensuring no Chymaeran spies are guising unwitting villagers. We hold the ceremonial rifles that we retrieved from the armory, clasped between our hands and upright, though Aldrin insists we "can't be fully trusted with them yet," and that we need to "train with a blade before we can handle them."

 My eyes steady on the vacancy in front of me on the other side of the road, originally intended to be held by Bertram. Before long, the shimmering white carriage prattles down the road, drawn by two black horses. They're looking to have a two-nights'-stay in the hot springs, and we're meant to prove to them that Gaffesend is safe, encouraging more tourists to make the trek to enrich our lands.

 I figure most of our population is excited for the presence of a Chosen Mask: we got the news that he was being paid to defend the carriage between villages. It's rare that anyone notable ever passes through, especially since we're the last stop before nothing. I can see him waving to his admirers from the coachman's seat as they cheer and throw flowers at the feet of the horses. Within the carriage, a finely-dressed family of six waves from the windows, wearing white and gold.

 I feel my hands loosen their tension on the rifle. The nagging feeling of fear that's plagued me since forever is almost in the back seat, and around me, I can drink to the exuberance of the town. To my left, Cae smiles, predictably not the type to cheer. To my right, Pax pumps his fist in the air. And Bertram is absolutely focused on the royals, standing there directly in front of me.

 The carriage is drawing closer, at least a hundred paces away. Some of the family's younger passengers have exited the carriage, walking alongside the road and tossing wrapped candies to the onlookers. The nagging feeling grows stronger. It's just too peaceful. And as my hands tension around the black steel, Bertram's eyes catch a glint of amethyst when he decides to make his move.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Body:
They're close enough to run me over, but my body's trained to react before I can think. Muscle memory comes before thought, thought before fear, and fear before true reaction, so it's only when I'm halfway across the road that the thoughts finally reach my muscles. The others are only beginning to notice when the Chymaeran fleshwalker raises the rifle. I'm the only one that happened to know enough and be close enough to respond, and when I try to take another step, I feel the gravity of my past flood my veins with molasses.

 I struggle to refuse the defenses of my own mind. I always swear I can taste the smoke from that fire when my heartbeat rises. And as the Chymaeran assassin guising my friend prepares to take aim and pull the trigger, all I can do is watch as I collapse to the street, giving the horses such a start that they shy and snort, rearing on their hind legs, casting the carriage forwards and backwards.

 Pax is quick on the uptake: for every dearth of common sense, he excels in his perception, tuned to that energy of the attacker. While the other junior guards only begin to notice, and the Chosen is left helpless in a battle of speed, the assassin pulls the trigger, spooking the horses and the spectators as Pax tackles him to the ground.

 I brace my head with my cheek brushing moss between the roadway stones. The coachman pulls the slip knot, and the horses' hooves clatter against the road, and I hold my breath, as if it could change the chances of the startled stallions shattering my spine or ribs. But they clamber right overhead, and as the carriage passes directly over my prostrated body lying straight with the road, I feel the wetness of something dense drip across my cheek.

 My ears still ring from the blast, but I can hear the cries of the children and the wife. And when I'm sure my whole body can still respond to its commands, I begin to crawl from beneath the carriage.

 "May the gods damn your pathetic town and its useless guards," the wife says. "It should be wiped off the face of the map!"

 I begin to imagine the repercussions, and I try to prepare myself for what's to come. I accept my fate to vanish from this program. I had my chance, and yet I couldn't even finish the job!

 The Chosen drags me out from beneath the carriage with his gloved hands. A long streak of the husband's blood stains my bangs and trickles down my nose. When I look to the inside of the white carriage, emptied of its crying inhabitants and bright with a splatter of red, I find the husband taking shallow breaths as he holds his shoulder, tended to by the glowing hands of their family's hired healer.

 The immaculately-dressed wife's jewelry clatters when she gets her hands around my collar, thrashing me as the Chosen hesitates to disarm his source of wealth. Her hands are already red with her lover's blood, clothes absent the pristine ivory white they surely struggled to sustain on such sultry trails.

 "You cowering, yellow-bellied bitch," she exclaims. Her gloved hand batters my cheek with deafening leather contact. "You leach our tribute. You live to give your lives for us, and I'll be sure you don't see another sunrise in this line of work. The guard of this backwater town are a joke!"

 I can feel my tears streaming, directly in the view of all my comrades that can only just stand there and watch. Jullian ducks his head when I meet his eyes. Cae freezes, her tail frayed. And Ryder and Pax are busy wrestling the Chymaeran as it tries to change forms.

 But I hear the husband. "Dear. That young guard is the reason my head is on my shoulders. I mean, Gods, if she hadn't given the horses a start..."

 "She nearly got you killed!"

 "The bullet did that," he says.

 "But still," she says. The mercurial woman releases my collar and tensions her fists, letting out an exasperated cry. The side of my face aches as I slouch, wiping my tears with the unsullied parts of my arms, remembering not to dirty their carriage with contact from my body.

 But it's the distress of the children that damages me the most. Standing on the other side of their life-altering trauma, facing such failure that I'm painted with the aggressor, the devastating shock registers on their faces, now devoid of sorrow, just speechless like I once was as they try to recalibrate their understanding of how horrifying the world can be. And all I want is to embrace them, to tell them that everything will be alright, to let them cry into my shoulder.

 "You failed us. And you're going to pay for this," the wife screams at Aldrin when he approaches. "How are you going to make this right?"

 "You'll make it right by apologizing to my officer," he says. "I don't care how much money you have, what role you play in the Empire, you will apologize for assaulting the woman who tried to save you!"

 "And failed," she insists. "You're messing with Valensend blood—"

 "You gave two days of warning for your arrival, refusing like all you rich types do to pay in advance, and then you have the gall to say we didn't prepare. It takes weeks!"

 The woman tensions her fists. Two of children grasp her dress by the fabric. I draw deep breaths to make the blood flow back into my fingers and legs, all the while feeling like I'm stealing a resource I no longer deserve.

 But I hear the father's voice behind me. "She would have complained the same if it was just a scare: I would have stopped her if I had the strength. As far as I'm concerned, you saved my life."

 "But I hesitated. I saved no one. It was luck."

 "Luck or not, you're a reason my children still have a father," he says. I turn around. He gestures for the servant and the healer to tend to my scratches, and with a quick wave of a hand, I feel the sting slowly dissipate from my face.

 He reaches from the open door, dabbing his blood from my skin with a clean corner of a towel, ensuring that nothing ill will come of this. Behind us, the two continue to argue as senior guards apprehend the battered Chymaeran assassin. It's only when I see the assailant's guise of my cherished friend that I remember the absence of the real one.

 I release an unintelligible string of words before the panic peaks inside me once again. Aldrin shouts. Two of my friends try to stop me, and the woman screams of my cowardice, but all I can think of is what I learned it takes for a Chymaeran to steal a guise.

 I run as fast as my feet will take me, choosing to try and save another, even if it means damnation for leaving this all behind.
