Manuscript.Synopsis: Cody tries to evade his deepening depression.
Manuscript.Summary:
> Nav introduces project. Reed overpraised.
> Cody struggles with change and ennui though Kei asks him out.
> Cody goes cold. But Katiya bangs on the door.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I can only work as fast as the computer will take me. I've spent so many hours between renders imagining how I would boost the performance if IT gave me a blank check and I was then the bottleneck — although a workstation laptop is nice to take home, it has nothing over one of those stationary rigs that the Robinson-Monroe lifers were grandfathered into.

 They gave me the laptop two years ago, and it hasn't been updated since. One day I booted into BIOS to see if I could overclock it, or take it to its limits. But IT's Great Wall of Control knows no bounds, so all I can do is sit here for twenty minutes at a time before I notice the changes in the drawing are applied.

 Those twenty minutes are silent. Only Wilbur and I sit in the row, and we're not even across from each other. Reed filled in the spot that the last escapee left behind, and although I was eager for months to move next to Kei and take the next steps, Navesh insisted it was a "major waste of time." I feel like Wilbur and I have exhausted every topic across the generational gap: his kids, when I plan to marry, if I have a serious girlfriend yet, cars, and sports. Every day I hear his wake apnea over the partitions, and sometimes I wonder if it's the perfect cover for him to be sleeping.

 The computer still holds an hourglass. It's midday, and the neighboring row is filled with chatter. I hear Reed's voice the most often, and a little too often: if golden retrievers could design and code, and the connotation didn't imply he was stupid, I think it would fit him well. Kei acknowledges his musings here and there, but is always so focused that she spits no more than a couple words.

 I check the calendar in the lower right corner of my screen. Fall is fast approaching, and when I count, it's been almost four weeks since I moved in. Four weekends of my parents coming over to visit, bringing over one of my favorite home-cooked meals, allowing them to ask when they'll have grandkids now that I have a house. Four weeks since I lost my brother's classic IPod, so now I listen to music on my phone. But also four weeks without drinking: most days I just go home, spend an hour on the computer scrolling my list of games, trying to convince myself to play something, and then go to sleep early unless I go to the gym with Miguel.

 Reed keeps rambling on about sports and hobbies, and the more I just sit there — helpless to walk over or else I'll look lonely and desperate — the more I wonder if I'm getting the right dose of meds. The longer time drags, and the later into my twenties it gets, the further I feel from the spurious passion of those college years where it was forced out of me. It's like being at the bottom of a dark pool, or a distant game of telephone recalling how I last recalled those moments. My vocal cords feel neglected for how little use they get, and like an unmotivated violinist, I've been unpracticed for a while.

 The render loads. It breaks the entire assembly, and I have another three keystrokes before I wait even longer.

 "Hey, Reed. Good job on the redline today," Nav says. "I hope you've been getting used to the software?"

 "Of course," he says. "Kei has been teaching me well. And Cody over there, too."

 I count the green-stamped pages on my desk. Three I've completed today. Maybe they just forget I work here?

 "So anyways. I want the three junior engineers to follow me," Nav says. I duck my head to look busy when he comes over. "Cody, can you follow us?"

 "Sure, Nav," I tell him.

 We gather in one of the small meeting rooms. I sit first near the door, then Kei and Reed sit together on the far side. Nav makes small talk when he's plugging in his laptop. "I haven't seen you at any of the happy hours, Cody," he says. "The whole team was there last week: what have you been so busy with?"

 "I even got Kei to go once," Reed says. "And she's usually busy all the time!"

 Kei smiles. "Yeah, I guess I can admit last week was a little fun. Even if it's just talking about guy stuff at a sports bar."

 Reed looks at me earnestly. I can tell that he means it. "You should come." He reminds me of my business major roommates in college, except before I had a legitimate excuse.

 "Yeah. Sounds like fun."

 "Well, tonight's the night. We were thinking Chili's," Nav says. "And you all have been doing great, so I thought I'd buy you all a drink."

 "Cheers to that!" Reed exclaims, raising an imaginary glass as I take a long draw of an energy drink. Nav flicks on the projector. His screen comes into focus, with a presentation labeled INTERMITTENT APPRENTICE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT, BY NAVESH D. PRATEL.

 "So I've been looking for ways to keep us busy. Things have been rather slow, and with Scott leaving and all —"

 "Scott's leaving?" We say in near unison.

 "Yeah. Oh, shoot — I was supposed to wait until Monday, gosh darn it," he says. "Keep this between us."

 "And what's going to happen?" Kei asks.

 "I don't know, with the hiring freeze and all, maybe something will come from within," Nav says. He winks so hard I think I hear it. "Anyways, on an unrelated note, I have a project to keep you guys busy, instead of vanishing early to go to Starbucks."

 "Awesome," Reed says, but literally.

 "We spend forever just designing and redesigning what already exists. It's what most of engineering is if you're not R and D, after all."

 Next slide.

 A 90's clip-art image of batteries is on the screen, each with little faces, shaking hands like little powered businessmen. I nearly laugh and I have to cover my mouth.

 "You spend so much time doing redlines as support engineers that you don't get to feel what it's like to come up with something. Surely you felt it in college. Maybe you've missed it."

 I nod almost as excitedly as Reed does.

 "Enclosures, and more enclosures. Modifying dimensions of existing batteries by the smallest hair to please a customer's plans. Well, I want you all to take a shot at designing something entirely new," Nav says. "You should know how batteries work from experience, not just designing the stuff they're housed in."

 "Yes, a million times yes," Reed says, and even Kei looks slightly invested.

 The next slide is a cross-section of a battery scanned from one of the lifers' textbooks, with such hand-drawn beauty there's no doubt it came from the seventies. I relish that it's finally something I'm good at, involving all the robotics I love to do in my garage.

 "What happens is a redox reaction, or reduction-oxidation," Nav says, sounding like my Circuits professor if he was twenty years older. "The anode has electron-rich elements like zinc, so it's negative. The cathode has elements like silver, so it's positive, and when you connect a wire from one to the other, you get electron flow."

 Next slide.

 "We typically do nickel-cadmium or lithium-ion, far better than the lead-acid ones. Then there's nickel-metal-hydride . . ."

 He drones on and on. With the energy drink death-gripped in my hand, I manage to stay awake: Reed can do it without anything. I decide to just wait for the email with the PowerPoint.

 "And, with all these considerations, your task will be to design an optimal battery, given a set volume. You'll do some theory, then we'll use the multimillion-dollar battery lab the R&D guys seem to have forgotten about."

 "That's great," Reed says.

 "How far you go with this project is up to you, and what you take from it is very important. You'll be doing this between redlines, getting feedback from Senior engineers, so that you design the best battery possible, and safely," he says, closing his laptop. "We'll be starting next week. And since it's Friday, maybe we can talk about it at Happy Hour."

 We all stand from the table. My foot falls asleep pretzeled on my other leg, so I stumble towards the door last. But before I can exit, Reed stops me.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Body:
"Hey bro. I was thinking we could talk about the project later," he says.

 What is this, an undergrad lab? Is there a grade?

 "Yeah, that'd be cool," I say.

 "What's your phone number? I already got Kei's last week. I was thinking we could make a group chat," he says.

 "Uh, yeah, man, sure." I take his phone. I enter CODY WORK in the top, and the ten digits in the box. He shoots me a text of the first three emojis in his "recent" bar, and then proceeds to make the group message right then and there.

 "Cool!" He says. "I was thinking, you look like you lift. Would you be down to lift before Monday?"

 I hardly even get in the door on time, dude, I want to tell him, but I'm short on friends and his energy is nostalgic for friends in a time long past. "Sure, I would like that," I tell him.

 "Great! I'll send you the one I go to. You can use my membership," he insists.

 I nod my head, still in my cooldown period for using "cool," "great," or "dope."

 The rest of the day passes slowly. I draw a couple concepts for the enclosure on sheets of TOPS engineering paper, an empty pad from never designing anything new. The late hour comes, and when the others begin to make their egress, it's just Kei and I.

 After shutting down. I pass her while she's deep in a design project. I'm surprised she notices.

 "Quite the eager guy, isn't he," she says.

 "Who, Reed?"

 "Yeah." She laughs. "Reminds me of you when you started here."

 "Oh, you mean before my soul got sucked from my body?" I approach her, pulling down my eyelids and rolling my eyes to expose the bloodshot whites. "Can you see it in there? Is it still alive?"

 She draws close to take a glance, and I catch a smell of familiar perfume from a date long forgotten. "Just enough, I think."

 I say, "I don't have energy like he does. That's for sure. And . . . it's lonely over there. Wilbur just snores all day, unless he's bashing his keyboard and cursing at the new software."

 "Well, then maybe I could make up for it," she says. But she's still focused on her drawing.

 "What do you mean?" I ask.

 "I mean we could hang out sometime. Like, outside of work," she says.

 My mind struggles to think of something platonic. "Oh. Like what?"

 "I don't know. The kind of stuff we used to do. But before, before..."

 Before that last summer before you left, I think. That was just Student Government stuff late in the evenings. Late work like this. I remember the last day of my junior year and her senior year, cleaning the room one last time as the Presidential cabinet, when I felt my heart swell in my chest with the apprehension of whether I was going to make my move. Time was running out. I had waited all year. The door was closed, and when she turned around, I pressed my lips to hers, and she dissolved into me, starting that perfect summer before she went—

 "Cody? I said we could do dinner." I was staring at her lips the whole time. It's a miracle I didn't raise half a chub, thanks to the waistband trick.

 "Yeah, that sounds great. I've got a couple Chuck E Cheese coupons I've been clipping out of the gazette."

 "What the fuck?" She laughs, something I haven't heard in a while. "See, this is the part of you I miss. There's surely still a soul in there."

 "I hope so," I say.

 "I'll shoot you a text," she offers, just as Reed sends another message in our group chat. All I can think of is how we left it last: letting the chance of starting anew decay over four years of college. It never had a title, but the split was worse than any other relationship I've been in.

 My mind is abuzz on the car ride home, so distracted the dark dissolves my sight of the exit gate, and I nearly ram it. I should be happy, but I feel some kind of sadness overtake me, and by the third light, I can feel my eyes well with tears. Maybe it's how fast the four weeks since moving in have gone. Maybe it's this unstructured emptiness into which my life retreats. Like Newton said about forces and stuff in motion, I feel like if nothing else ever acted on me, I'd float in this job at this level and at this social vapidness until I hit the mahogany wood of my coffin.

 I don't know how Reed or my late brother Jackie seem to find it. That energy to reach beyond, and every time I reach the end of this line of thinking, I wish it was the one lesson my older brother could have passed down to me.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Body:
I toss my keys on the counter: the house is a moderate mess when my parents aren't coming the day after. I slip my hand down my pants and grab the TV remote (not for porn), fixing the sweaty adhesion I'd dealt with since the afternoon.

 Reed messages about the happy hour in the involuntary group chat. He reminds me of my brother. And, surprisingly, Kei says she's going, too.

 They ask me if I'm coming, but the darkness of the foyer is too comfortable. All I want is to do nothing, so the minutes pass until the hour passes and I still haven't responded, just sitting there, wondering why I don't feel much of anything.

 Before long I'm lost in dreamless sleep, and the next moment, I awake in my boxers to a loud disturbance next door. The oven clock reads 2:17 AM. There's a loud banging on the door. It's that strange adjoining door, connecting my flat with my neighbor's. Beyond the odd noises from the adjoining townhouse, I haven't touched the over engineered doorstop since.

 "Help me, please," the voice pleads, in an accent or a dialect I can hardly understand.

 I stumble through blackness for the door.

"Cody," she sobs.

> Katiya barely saves Bertram.
> Everyone laments Katiyathough Aldrin tries to defend her. Alone, she can only reach out to Cody.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Body:
Calling his name will do nothing. I decide ahead of time to break in instead of patiently knocking, hoping the others piece together my purpose for panic instead of thinking I'm just deserting. My two friends are built like bricks, but it's all the muscle that helps in a sprint. If Bertram's house were any further than three blocks, they might have fallen behind. My legs are long and my conditioning is great, but it's not enough. I feel one of them lift me into the air as I continue to struggle, like a rabbit caught in an eagle's clutches.

 "Let me go! He's not out sick, he's dying," I say.

 "I know," Ryder says. "I checked the Chymaeran's things. He didn't have a Guise Marker on him, so he didn't have the time to sever a finger. You know it takes a while to process."

 "It wasn't meant to be a permanent guise. It was just for a moment, so it's off blood. That means Bertram has to be alive to keep it going," Pax says.

 "You're not doing this alone," says Ryder, finally putting me down. "We're going to help him together."

 "Fine. But the guise isn't active anymore," I tell them, as we begin to run at even pace. "He has no need to be alive."

 We pass the market street, then sprint along the road at the edge of the lake. I collect speed with distance, and by the time we arrive at Bertram's gate, I leverage all my Essence and anger against his door, bashing my armored shoulder against the painted wood.

 The door splits in splintered halves. The dust and sawdust coalesce in dark, floating motes as the sun casts ribbons of light through the entryway, and I squint my eyes to adjust to the darkness of his house. There is not a sound to tell his whereabouts. We enter the kitchen to find the window ajar with the curtains fluttering, the same window I use to trade for breakfast.

 "He's not on the bottom floor," I say. It's just a single, long room that mixes the kitchen with a living space and dining area. None of the chairs are overturned, and the mess looks average for a single man.

 We begin to climb the stairs. Pax insists on going first, followed by Ryder, followed by me, with my dagger drawn hilt-up. They know the hallway design is two rooms and a master, so they split off to take the other rooms, leaving me with the only place my friend can feasibly lie.

 We throw the doors open at the same time. I hear no commotion from the other two, and as I approach the bed, I see the sheets are clean, crumpled with a pallid figure sweating in short trousers.

 "Bertram," I say.

 He's breathing heavily, still unable to move, and veins of amethyst metastasize in a rash across his skin.

 "Clear," the others report, entering the bedroom to find me kneeling beside his bed.

 "How bad is it? Do you know?" I ask Pax. "He's breathing, and he's not bleeding, what did they do to him?"

 Pax presses his fingers to Bertram's neck. The room gets colder as his fingertips flush with obsidian. "The guise is up, so he's not being drained any longer, but he'a really on the edge."

 "Drained?" I ask.

 "The blood," Pax says. "For a short guise like this that doesn't take a pound of flesh, it evaporates from his body every minute, damaging his organs. He'll wish he lost a finger instead."

 "We need to heal him right away," I say, extending my hands, but Pax stops me.

 "Human Essence will only make this worse. It's like treating frostburn with warm water."

 "Then what do we do?" I ask.

 "There's medicine at the base, but it's really up to him until we can get him there. He's got to fight," Pax says. "The worst is over, but I only know l as far as experimenting with my Chymaeran blood has gotten me. I'll still monitor the Curse."

 "And I'll carry him," Ryder says.

 "We need to keep him warm," I say. He's sweating so profusely, but I tuck the sheets around him, feeling his flesh is colder than ice. I press my head to his chest, listening to his faint heartbeat. "It's my turn to save you," I tell him, standing back as Ryder works to position him across the back of his shoulders.

Beyond his window, the curious villagers and guards begin to gather, and I pray that Aldrin will have the understanding. I follow Pax and Ryder to the gates of the base on the route of our daily walk, using Essence to help sustain his warmth beneath the blanket.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Summary: Katiya crosses over in a panic attack. Cody stays with her until she falls asleep. Cody stays up in garage working on drone.
Manuscript.Body:
Words are a currency she can't afford when her panic sets her over the edge. She speaks in strings of syllables I can't comprehend, but it's not her desperate cries that confuse me the most.

 It's the fact that the last four weeks passed so peacefully. I thought this was all just a dream after that drunken night with Miguel, but the beautiful girl I mistook for a cosplayer chokes on her tears between breaths as she buries her face into my arm.

 "They've all abandoned me," she says. "I failed to . . . he almost died, because . . ." My fingers trace her back until I realize I'm just touching her armor (and it's doing nothing for her). I gently guide her back against the couch. For every extra breath of air she finds, she shells it out in useless ramblings that drive her further into a panic, tensioning her body inwards as the tears flow from her face.

 She tensions her hands around my arm so strongly that the blood starts seizing in my own limb.

 "Save your breath," I tell her. "You have to breathe. Whatever happened has passed, and it's over now. You're safe here."

 "But the town—"

 "The town is fine," I tell her, uncertain of what delusion could cause such a visceral reaction. It was all a fever dream, right? I remember getting sliced across the palm, but I woke up without a scratch. The girl's my neighbor: just a whacked-out cosplayer. Maybe someone reported her stream to the IRS for tax evasion?

 She finds more words as her trembling subsides. "I only came here because . . . I had no other choice, and as much as I wish I never had to see you again . . ."

 "Excuse me?" I ask.

 "I mean . . . as much as I know we hate each other, after—"

 "— I don't hate you," I tell her. But then the semantics of that lucid dream come back to me. The cut in my palm. The kitchen knives she threw at my head. "Not that much, I mean." And then I remember the gash she sliced in my championship lacrosse stick that got me from freshman benchwarmer to Varsity senior. "I'm just afraid of you. And—and you piss me off a little, but not that much," I say, trying to balance the resurgent feelings of vice with a desire for goodwill.

 Her stress slides further from panic into sorrow, exchanging less heaving breaths for more tears. She's dressed entirely in her custom light armor: I'd think she'd only need it above the torso to film a Let's Play in character, but she's committed to the part.

 "Hey. Let's get that armor off of you," I tell her. She reaches for the faux-leather straps on the sides, and when I grab the shoulder pads, I find them oddly cold to the touch.

 I try lifting as she lifts her arms, but it's pretty heavy for light armor. The fabric feels hand-woven, with the smallest imperfections that tell of old-world craftsmanship. It smells of sweat and manual labor. And as I struggle to pull it off her body, I notice the contours of the breastplate are caught on something beneath.

 "Ow," she sniffles. "Let me loosen the straps more."

 "You got this made of actual metal? Cast iron?"

 "What else would stop an arrow?" She asks, holding her breath as I tug harder. Once she finds enough breath to go without it, she exhales completely, and in an instant, I lose my balance and trip over one of the unpacked boxes from four weeks ago.

 The entire weight of the armored torso lands on my face when I crash to the floor. My hands cup the meager metal chest contours of modified men's armor, weighing against my face and smelling of sweat as if I were stuck in a scrum of lacrosse players.

 But I can hear her breathe easier without the burden of all that cosplay gear. Her breathless panic makes even more sense when I rid my face of the breastplate, discovering how much she has to contort herself just to fit into the damn thing.

 She removes the last of her bindings, far tighter than the "combat corset" that constrains her waist. She pulls at the fabric of the undershirt to circulate air, where two large sweat spots accentuate the shape of her chest.

 Her face and golden eyes alone could get a zoomer to watch her stream Excel spreadsheets: if she ditched the immersive armor and went for something less practical, she could be living in a mansion!

 I open my mouth to try to distill that compliment into something platonic, but stop when I see the state of her. Her disheveled hair is frayed far past the braid I first saw her with. Crescents dig beneath her eyes, and as she still works at slowing her breaths — muttering to herself something about "where she is" — I can see how tired this whole ordeal has made her, and my feelings of malice slip away.

 She sits with her head in her hands, tensioning her fingers around her scalp. I'd offer her a hug if I didn't think she still hated me, so instead, I decide to warm her with something else.

 I approach the kitchen, starting the coffee maker to make some hot chocolate my mom left from the old house. I watch her golden eyes peer over the edge of the couch when the heating element starts boiling the water, like my parents' cat when the refrigerator makes ice.

 "It's not Starbucks," I tell her.

 She tilts her head. "What is it doing?"

 "Boiling water?" I answer.

 "Huh." She leans higher, watching the flickering blue LED light with a genuine sense of bewilderment. "So you do have Essence. Why didn't you use it?"

 "Essence?" I ask.

 "Essence. To run the mechanism: top off the Essence capacitor. Like a stove, or a fan, or..."

 "It runs on electricity."

 "Electricity?" She asks. "What a waste. How do you have that much power? And how rich are you to have all this," she gestures around the living room, "stuff?"

 She still finds the strength to do her bit, despite whatever wore on her. "I bought most of it at Home Goods and that corner part of Ross without the clothes. I'm far from rich when I have a mortgage hanging over my head now," I tell her.

 "You must make a lot of Kine off your inventions."

 "Not yet. I get paid to modify other people's stuff," I tell her. My hands reach into the cabinet, finding the old matching mugs Kei and I bought for the Student Government club room. I hesitate over which one to grab, then after the coffee maker pings, I grab my own.

 The old coffee maker dispenses the succulent store-bought chocolate into the mug, rising with steam as dots of moisture condense on the blue inner walls of the porcelain. But it doesn't feel very warm.

 "Oh. It's a drink," she says.

 I look at her, puzzled, until she gestures to bring it over.

 "It's an old coffee maker from my parents' house. They got a new Keurig, so they let me have the old one — the model before it scanned the damn pods to make sure you're buying theirs. Heating element isn't great, so hopefully it's not like drinking chocolate milk."

 "Not a problem," she says, taking the cup into her hands. I notice a faint glow emanate from beneath the cup as the air warms around her, and in seconds, the cup is steaming again.

 It's my turn for bewilderment. She catches my expression with a tired glance.

 "What?"

 "How did you...?"

 I bend to look beneath the mug, but there's nothing there. Once I realize it looks like I'm staring directly at her breasts, I bend upright.

 "What kind of an uncultured bumpkin are you?" She asks. "Life and fire. Humans. You. Me," she says, raising her right hand to pretend she's bending fire.

 Pretending, right?

 I feel the heat first. And then at a point an inch above her palm, a spark transitions into a raging plume of controlled fire, casting the walls in flickering light.

 I instinctively reach to see if it's a hologram. I feel burning heat before she ceases, slapping my hand away.

 "You grab for fire like you grabbed for that dagger," she says. "Pray tell, what kind of stupid idiot savant are you?"

 I stammer over my words. My mind races through every physics and thermodynamics textbook I've ever skimmed for problem sets, and can't find any explanation. The sudden wave of confusion is so strong that I sit down on the box I tripped on moments earlier. "Sweet Carnot," I say.

 "Is that one of your gods?"

 "If you design cars and airplanes," I say. "What the fuck?" And then I gesture to her. "Do it again. How did you do that?"

 I'm too damn tired, she says.

 "Do it," I insist, like a child at a birthday magic show.

 She casts it again as she takes her first sip from the mug, careful to watch if I'll try and reach for it again, but I raise my hands.

 Her eyes light with delight. It seems like an emotion she hasn't felt in a long time.

 "This is really good," she says. "What is it?"

 "Hot chocolate. From the grocery store. But really, though. How did you—"

 She takes another loud sip. "I usually hate sweet stuff. But this is nice." She warms it further with her hands: the mug glows with conductive heat, and then she drinks all the rest of it in a single swallow.

 Now I have my head in my hands, unsure whether I really want to know the secret behind her sleight-of-hand.

 "You really have never seen this before? Even a child can make a spark," she insists, reclining back into the couch as her eyes feather on the edge of exhausted sleep.

 "I'm not a damn child," I tell her. "It's not real. You can't just..." but then I realize she's fading away on the couch: it must be comfortable if it makes Miguel fade away this easily, too.

 I take the mug by the handle and rinse it in the sink. The red-hot bottom evaporates the first volume of water to steam before it normalizes, and I flip it upside-down into the dish organizer, since I haven't run the dishwasher in a week and I can't remember if it's all dirty or not. On the bottom, I inspect the words I wrote almost a decade earlier.

 STU GOV KING + QUEEN

 2016

 She breathes so softly on the couch that I almost forget she's there. And when I approach, I find her deep in sleep: sweating again, muttering something about a cabin as her right hand searches for something.

 She mutters a name.

 I don't hear it.

 "Stay," she asks, as tears crest again in her eyes, and I sit on the box again, as her hand feels for something like fronds of a flower feeling for the sun, finding its way to mine.

And once it finds me, it refuses to let go.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Summary: Next morning, awkward breakfast. She's embarrassed. He's weirdly calm.
Manuscript.Body:
I wake again from dreams of fire. My hand is always first to feel for the other side of the bed, but my fingers are already laced in something.

 I long so deeply for something warm to hold. I want the heat to quell my panic, to overwrite the memories and feelings that sensation brings with something warm that's better. The cabin is collapsing again: no windows or doors, just a hot box of logs crumbling under the weight of my father's weakness, and I can feel my own muscles tension further in whatever I can grab to ease the pain.

 My eyes feather open to the light of an unfamiliar sun. The birds sound different. The space smells like the industrial quarter of Northaven, and when I feel the sensation of feathers against my neck, I wonder if I squeezed another pillow so hard that the stuffing came out.

 But it's the hair of a man. Not my man. But a man that mumbles something with his face buried between my breasts as I tension him further.

 When I release him, he gasps, and I notice the spread of blankets on the floor. One of the couch's pillows is on the ground, and a scrounging of scavenged blankets makes a meager bed. His face is flushed with a mix of several dissimilar emotions he can't resolve, and mine flushes further when I realize what I've done.

 "Y-you know how lucky you are that it's a Saturday?" he says. "I could barely reach for enough to make a bed to get a couple hours of sleep! Then pulling me in like that? And I don't even know your name," he says.

 "Katiya," I tell him. "Katiya Breakey-Hilde. And you're . . . Cody?"

 "Yeah," he says, wiping the sweat from my chest off both sides of his face. "At least I had my phone with me. I ordered us something: you can pay me later."

 I look at the laughable spread of blankets and bedsheets again, more concerned about the duress I put him under. "You could have let go. I mean, you don't even know me. Why didn't you force my hand away and get a good night of sleep?"

 His voice quiets on a hint of humiliation. "Well, you know, you were crying and all. Said not to leave, again and again, and your grip is pretty strong, so..."

 "So you didn't leave," I say. Something makes me want to tear up again when a strange sense of relief approaches, but I'm done being weak and sentimental. "Well, thank you."

 "Sure. But you can do me a favor and take a shower?" he asks.

 "Excuse me?" I ask.

 "It smells like you haven't showered in a week," he says.

 "I can't afford a shower," I tell him. "I went in the lake last week, then took a bath, like, four days ago."

 "Really? You can afford to shower. It's not like the drought three years ago."

 "Can't afford A SHOWER," I clarify, gathering my things like a mistress of the night.

 "It comes with the damn unit!" Cody exclaims. "How could you possibly not have a shower? There were only two options in the builder's package. Either Mantequilla, or—"

 "Wait," I say, putting my hand to his mouth. A shadow approaches the door of his house that's so immaculate and messy at the same time. "Did you hear that?"

 "Probably just the delivery driver," I say.

 "That's not a knocker." I reach for the knife I kept hidden in the side holster of my breastplate, ready to pounce as soon as the adversary blasts open the door. Cody is too weak to defend himself.

 "Yo, chill! Chill out. Look," he says, showing me a brightly-lit device with far more little colored squares than the music box. A cartoon of an automobile is on the screen, dancing around the center of a map. "You don't have to stab first and ask questions later, soldier girl."

 "And you don't have to grab fire and blades, foolish boy," I respond.

 He cracks the door. I rise to my feet and find the footing to attack, but when the door opens, some bearded guy with earrings and fancy glasses hands a bag to him. Cody mutters some question about whether the tip of something is in an app, and then he nods, allowing him to close the door, and when I catch a glimpse of the scene beyond the door, I realize again that it looks nothing like Gaffesend.

 I rush to the window, throwing open the shades. "Where is this? Where are you? And where's the lake?" I ask. I begin to think it's all a ruse to trap me at my weakest.

 "A couple blocks down. You think I could afford lakeside in this economy?" He asks. "But the walk is nice."

 Before he can hand me something from the bag, I race back across the threshold of my door, only to find my world the same way I left it. From my window, Gaffesend is abuzz with the week's end sight of commoners strolling on the cobblestone streets.

 "Katiya," Cody calls. "Do you want your tacos or not?"

 "Cody," I say. "This is..."

 He crosses the threshold of the door, finding the same sight he must have thought was just a dream. Now he rushes to my window, watching the water reflect in the light of an early-morning sun.

 I'm glad he put the bag down in the other world. He clutches his chest, short of breath, and I think the man of science is finally beginning to understand that the world is not as measurable as he thinks.

 His face flushes white as if he's seen a Chymaeran fleshwalker. I have to catch him before he falls, and I grab him by the space between his arms.

 "You weren't — you mean that—" Cody tries to struggle from my grasp to walk out my front door for the first time by his own volition, but his clothes are far too strange: they might think he's a Chymaeran spy, or ask his noble heritage.

 "Stop resisting," I command, hugging him to my chest. I realize I'm speaking my own tongue now, and he's speaking mine, and I say, "seriously, can you stop fighting me when I'm trying to help you?"

 "Do it again," he says, slumping in dead weight before he collects himself, rising to his feet half a head taller than me. "Do the fire trick again."

 I roll my eyes. "It's not a trick, Cody."

 "Do it," he says, then adds, "please," staring at me with his dark brown eyes.

 I light a simple flame. He looks on with such stupid, childlike captivation that I wonder what other dumb banality could capture his attention.

 "Holy shit," he says. "And how do you do that?"

 "Watch this," I say.

 I direct the energy to form a loop of flame, spinning around my palm. And some of the other stupid tricks the cadets used to come up with. "So can we eat now?"

 "I guess it will never get cold," he says.

 "So you live your whole life without Essence?" I ask him. "So you're some kind of purist monk?"

 He responds in my tongue again without noticing he's doing it. "No Essence at all. Just electricity: there's no magic in our world."

 "But what about the cars?" I ask.

 "A four-stroke engine that runs on dead dinosaurs." I don't catch the meaning of the last word, but my mind associates it with creatures from an eternity ago. He clarifies. "Gasoline. Hydrocarbons from crude oil."

 "It's as if the world wasn't made for you. As if your world never had the blessings of the Gods."

 "We don't know if there is a god, beyond money and power," Cody says. "They certainly haven't introduced themselves in person."

"Well, let's eat," I insist. "Before it gets cold, or before I have to warm it up again."

Manuscript.Label: Paragate
Manuscript.Synopsis: Cody gives Katiya a lazy day in Hearthland Ridge.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Summary: Katiya gets a lazy day, gradually introduced to things. Set ground rules for roommateship.
Manuscript.Body:
I never knew it was possible to misunderstand a taco. It seems pretty obvious that it's tall and narrow. That you have to rotate the thing sideways to put it in your mouth to take a bite, but Katiya wedged her teeth between the middle of the shell, taking bites like a chipmunk as she complained that the shell might spill it all.

 Nor did I ever consider how the taste of processed food might be too much for someone that eats an antiquated diet of fruit and bread and meat, taken aback by how salted the ground beef was, though she liked gnashing her teeth on the crunch of the shell when she finally figured out that she had to turn her head.

 I let her stop there, hiding the soda I got for her in the fridge in fear that the carbonation might make it shoot out of her nose.

 "You said you don't have plans, right?" I ask.

 "I got two whole days for all this to boil over," she says.

 "But your friend—Bertram? What about him?"

 "I got a telegram that he's stable," she says, "so it will be a little while before I see him again."

 "Telegram," I repeat. "And your boyfriend? Julian?"

 "I don't know," she says.

 "I'd think he would check on you after all that, don't you think? He should care about you."

 Katiya's eyes narrow. "I think he's ashamed of me, or something." I ball my fists. She notices, and tries to defend him. "But I really, really messed up."

 "You told me. But I think people that love you should love you through anything, you know?"

 She tucks her arms together in her hands as if she could ever shiver. "I just don't really want to talk about it," she says.

 "Then how about we get to your 'rest day?'"

 "A rest day?" She glares at me, disgusted. But from the tone of her body, I guess it takes some kind of psycho to be that well-conditioned.

 "A day to recover before you get back to . . . whatever it is you do. I thought it was streaming, but if you're really a city guard, then that explains a lot."

 "Probational city guard," she clarifies, as if I should care.

 "Cool."

 "But I think first — we should set some ground rules for sharing this space."

 "Huh," I say. "Leave it to the city guard to go rambling on about making laws."

 "But seriously," she says, beaming a look of sincerity through her actually-amber eyes. "We have to set boundaries or else things could worsen."

 "I guess, but do we have to do that right now? Let's put it off. It's the weekend."

 "I don't do week's ends," she states, in a sinister voice that almost raises gooseflesh on my arms.

 "Alright, alright," I tell her, raising my hands, feeling like a complete couch potato. "We'll go for a drive later, then. So: where's your quill and ink, so we can write up this document? Did you pluck the pheasant for a fresh tip?"

 "We have pens, you nonce," Katiya says.

 I grab an old notebook from engineering school and flip it to an empty page near the back. I grab a pen from the ground, only to realize it's one of Miguel's disposable vape pens he forgot to pick up.

 Katiya laughs, muttering something.

 "What was that?" I demand.

 "Like a child," she says. "With all your fancy science, your children don't learn to write without lines?"

 "Piss off," I tell her. And then I add, "Maybe if your world could come up with half this shit instead of relying on Essence, you'd be able to buy a shower instead of using mine," I tell her. "Maybe that's the first rule." I reach for an actual pen in one of the boxes. "Don't ever get too comfortable with the other world's stuff, though that's probably more for you, right?"

01. Never depend on the other world's things.

 "You haven't been introduced to any of my world's amenities yet," she says.

 "And what else?" I scribble circles in the corner of the page.

 She looks at the couch before looking at me, probably remembering an hour ago when she hugged my head to the space between her breasts. "And no sleeping over in the other world. Ever," she says.

 I write it on the third line in block letters.

02. Never spend the night in the other world.

 "Why all capital letters? Are you writing in the voice of an angry god, giving commandments?"

 "No," I say, taking my time to write out the line. "And I have a third one: it's a two-parter. No bringing people across the threshold from your world. And no telling anyone about any of this."

03. No one else can cross the threshold.

04. No one else can know about the door.

She adds another one about loud music and sound, as if I didn't already live around old people. And I add one about using my utilities excessively. And bringing weapons in here. She adds one about being in her world dressed as strangely as I am now, and I counter with a corollary saying she can't dress like an e-girl unless it's Halloween or the Renaissance Faire. She says not to go out in Gaffesend without her. I say she doesn't have a license, so she shouldn't go out in my world either.

05. No loud music or sound, especially at night.

06. Don't burn a hole in Cody's wallet using his utilities.

07. No weapons in Cody's world.

08. Thou shalt dress like a commoner when in the other person's world. No out-of-place clothes.

09. NEVER go out alone in the other world.

 "And last of all," she says, thirty minutes later, "is the most important." I have space for one more before I'd have to flip over the page. "Our worlds are meant to be apart. So we can't ever get together."

 "Like hang out?" I ask.

 "No, you idiot," she says. Her cheeks are a little redder. "Like, get together, you know. Love. Fall in love."

 "Oh. Oh, no," I say. "I already have someone I like. And you have that guy."

 "Jullian," she says.

 "Yeah," I say, shaking off the sweat in my palm before I finish off the page. It's strange how she detests that four-letter word so much: probably something about weakness.

10. Never fall for each other. Ever.

  "Okay. Is that enough?"

 "For now," she says.

 "How about 'have fun?'"

 "Fun isn't common in my world," she says, sternly again. "Sloth is a fatal sin that kills you at a young age."

 "Christ. Calm down, Nietzsche," I tell her. "We're going to be having fun going for a drive, right?"

 "I just want to understand your world. It's dangerous to me. So just understand," she insists, "that's all."

"Whatever you say," I tell her, grabbing the keys to my car and heading for the garage.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Summary: First car ride with Cody: terrified at speed and they nearly crash.
Manuscript.Body:
He spends a near ten minutes trying to find twenty different ways to demand that I sit in the exact same place without touching anything. That I'm safe. That I can't possibly get hurt, regardless of how fast we go. That anything foreign and strange and big and too impossibly smooth is there for a reason, and that nothing is going wrong unless he says it is, and that he'll surely bring it up if things are even slightly bad.

 He doesn't press the glowing switch on the wall for a reason, facing the large metal door that looks like it isn't supposed to open from the sides. The automobile is so smooth and metallic: shinier than my greatsword, and probably one of the shiny things he told me not to touch.

 But he instructs me to enter. Then he looks down at my feet and realizes I'm wearing steel boots, and demands more of me, telling me to lace up a pair of his "trainers" though they look nothing like shoes of war.

 And once my feet fill the space like two parishioners in a grand chapel to the Gods, he tells me to GENTLY! pull the handle, afraid of my strength.

 I sit in the car on the comfortable seat, wondering why everything is so soft in this world that you could fall asleep on it: even the people, from the kind of food Cody's shown me so far. And then he presses a button on a wide mirror that opens the door to this car room: sounding off with a loud rumble of a generator that nearly sets me into panic.

 He reassures me that it's all okay. But then something flashes on his automobile's front thing about blue teeth being connected, and I hear the loudest sound I've ever heard: one that gives me such a start that I notice it gives him a start, and according to his original rules, that means that I should panic.

 His hand slams against the circular knob as I almost drive my fist against the glowing screen, but he deflects my hand just in time. He wags his finger several times at me before pulling out his cellular telephone to change something, saying that music about metal is probably too much for me, that he was just at the gym.

 I ask him what they're yelling about. He says he doesn't really know, but that it gets him "amped" at the gymnasium, and chooses some other thing that tells the sonograph to play another tune.

 He backs out of the space slowly. His eyes flicker between my face and the edge of the car port that's close to the metal door, and I nearly slam my head against the front with the sudden change in inertia.

 He presses his left arm against my shoulders, telling me to relax. And when he's beginning to second-guess himself of this whole plan, saying that he's only "adding fuel to the fire that is my anxiety," and that I'm never going to relax at this rate.

 I tell him I'm not made to relax, and that I've faced worse than his soft world with all these rounded edges could ever throw at him.

 So we back out of the driveway. I tense my legs and feet against the bottom of the car to make sure my back is always against the soft chair, and when he makes his first full quarter-turn backwards into the street, something closes the big steel door.

 He asks if I'm alright. I ask if he's going to stop asking if I'm alright, and when my eyes look up from my legs to take in the view beyond the warped front glass, I see a marvel of architecture in front of my eyes.

 It's like the town of Gaffesend with all its row-houses, but cleaner and sharper. There are children here that play in the street: the young ones at least, the older ones sit in the corners on telephones like the one that Cody has, laughing at something as they share it with each other. One man sprays a dedicated stream of water from a hose to wet his plants. There are so many other cars that sit all across the road: behind the car garages, on the streets off to the side, so many that I wonder if they have cars this comfortable, why they would need a house in the first place.

 I wonder aloud. It makes Cody laugh pretty hard, and he manages to collect himself by the first red octagon with the words STOP written across it.

 I don't allow the inertia to surprise me this time. But the right turn does, and I lean so far into Cody that I have to stabilize myself by grabbing his right leg, causing him to slam the brake and throw himself forward.

 He barks at me, but without bite, gesturing to a handle attached to the top edge of the car, something he calls the "oh-shit handle," insisting I grab it until I get my bearing. Several seconds later, he changes his mind and tells me not to, afraid I might rip it off the roof.

 But I'm too amazed by the sights to tense my body for any turns. When the view of houses opens up after a couple turns, and the musical automobile climbs a slight hill, I catch a fuller view of the city: spanning so far that my eyes can't count the number of buildings. Not a single stretch of farmland is anywhere: just buildings erected from the colors of nature around them; shiny points of light that shimmer in the mountains; large balloons of color with people in them that hover above the lake.

 "And none of this is Essence," I ask.

 And Cody nods with ease.

 My mind doesn't even know what to process from what my eyes observe, like the late-night lectures in school when all the cadets are too tired to retain anything. My chest stirs with an animated lightness unlike anything I think I've ever felt before, except maybe when I was a young child, and although it scares me — and it's probably a little from Cody as the operator — I feel an odd calmness when I'm next to him, listening to the faint voice he tries to hide when he sings the words to the songs he likes.

 The cabin is pleasantly cool despite how hot it might be out there. He gestures to a part of the car that shows a number that resembles the temperature, instead of a thermometer.

 I bring my head close to the air conditioning. He asks if I really want to have my hair blown, and lowers the window, filling the space with a deafening gust of air until he lowers his window, telling me to reach my hand beyond the cabin.

 We race so fast that the air floods through my fingers like water in a stream, and I realize I'm laughing, but I don't stop myself too much. We get on the highway, and though he's apprehensive of whether I'll try to slice the seat belt and jump out the window, I find it amazing: thrilling that any person could have such an ease of access to the sensation of speed.

 There are so many other people of this world inside these cars that I wave at them, but Cody tells me not to. He then demands that I "don't speak to anyone yet" and "don't call anything anything to anyone" and to "mask my surprise a little" when we get to our destination.

 We get off the highway and end up on slower and smaller roads for a while, stopping at crossroads where some light operator tells us when we can drive. One fellow blares his horn really loud, enough to anger Cody to use some gesture on him, speaking words I can't yet fully understand, but he calms down when he remembers that I'm here, saying he "forgot that I could smite them."

 We end up on a wide square of painted lines in organized rows. Cody stops the automobile between two pairs of them, between two other cars, and instructs me to CAREFULLY! open the car door and not touch the other car door next to me.

 I step out into the space between cars, my stomach a little twisted, but my body feeling light. He gestures to a big building with a word that doesn't translate, because he says it's a company called Costco, and that they have more stuff to eat and wear and buy than I could ever imagine.

 I can feel a hint of the panic set in when I realize I'm surrounded by other commoners of his world for the first time. I'd retreat back into the car if Cody didn't coax me out by gently grabbing my shirt, telling me that if I stick with him, I'll be fine.

 He offers his hand to me, and I hesitate. But right when I'm about to take it, he pulls away, apologizing, saying that I can walk right next to him.

 He points to a row of metal baskets, telling me to grab one. I lift it by the side. His face flushes in secondhand embarrassment when he shows me that there are wheels on the bottom for a reason, and though the wheels are halfway to my waist, I drop the cart as people stare.

 He says it's fine, drawing into his pockets for a small card with patterned lines on it, saying something about hot dogs and some guy that raises them for cheap, instructing me to push the cart as we enter the big warehouse, making sure that I don't make eye contact with anyone.

Manuscript.Label: Generative Revision
Manuscript.Summary: Costco: possibly run into Kei or Miguel or someone.
Manuscript.Body:
"Just try not to make too much eye contact with anyone," Cody says. "They already think you do dress-up from the color your eyes are."

 "But how could they? Are there any other races here?"

 "Just humans," Cody says. "So boring and dissimilar we call different skin colors different races, can you believe that?"

 "No," I tell him, pushing the cart by its wheels instead of lifting it by the side.

 The store is so flooded with people that it reminds me of my late childhood in the capital. But it seems that all the vendors are owned by the same people — the dog guy that Cody was talking about.

 I spot three exits to the building in case anything happens, Cody tugs the cart past the massive screens, showcasing views of other worlds so real you can't even see the tiny little dots of color, and I begin to wonder whether it's a doorway like the one between our homes.

 But Cody reads my mind. "Not a portal," he says. "Those are televisions."

 "Where do they go?" I ask. "I thought you had to project the pictures from a box."

 "Nowhere. You'd probably get electrocuted if you stuck your head in there," he says.

 He goads me onward, passing an array of smaller screens in the telephone format that Cody has, called Smartphones, filled with so much knowledge it's like the Verdala and their network of wisdom trees.

 I try not making eye contact, but it's unfathomable to see a crowd of people without a single cat-eared Ahkvasan or mixed-race person. And to think they all have no Essence at all: something that terrifies me if I imagine they were invaded.

 I try to spin up some conversation instead of asking Cody foolish questions. "Say, who is that girl that you admire?"

 "Which one?"

 "The mug girl," I say. "From work."

 He laughs. "Mug girl. You mean Kei?"

 "Yeah, Kei," I say. "How are things with her?"

 His grasp tightens around the mesh of the cart as I push it. "I don't know. I'm not really sure," he says. "We used to be really close: we kissed, even. Things were getting good, then she left for college because she was a year ahead of me."

 I ask, "Did you have intercourse with this woman?"

 Cody convulses, grabbing my shoulder before he realizes we're alone in the aisle. He sighs. "Katiya. You can't just talk about that out loud," he says.

 "Why not?" I ask.

 "Because people aren't always that open to talking about stuff like that."

 "Why should we care?" I ask, sincerely.

 "Because it's etiquette. Sex, drugs, stuff like that, makes people uncomfortable, so it's better to talk in private."

 "Then how does anyone have . . . that level of engagement in your society?"

 "It's on the phone now," he whispers. "You wouldn't just walk up to someone and ask for it, would you?"

 "Well, in the poor parts of Northaven, when—"

 "—Don't answer that," he says, taking the cart over from me.

 "So this girl," I start. "The one you didn't have," and I almost laugh, "business with."

 He sneers at me. "Yeah. We were too young for that, kind of. And then college was busy — sleeping around and stuff without anything real, and now the stupid, boring, lonely, real world you're thrust into after all that, when you have to pay off the student loan and become indebted to a piece of land."

 "But how could you ever be bored or lonely? Bored of this?" She lifts a kids' drawing kit, and then a card with a Nintendo Switch depicted on it. "And how could you be lonely when you're literally connected to everyone?"

 Some passersby overhears her rant, and adds, "You're goddamn right."

 "Then welcome to the modern age, and the biggest problem we've created that we can't solve," I tell her, turning the corner of the last aisles on the first side of the store that get into the liquor. "Be glad you're not included in it."

 "But you don't have to do any of that."

 "Not when everybody else does," I muse. "Imagine if everybody spoke a special language, and you decided not to learn it."

 "Then they should speak the old language."

 "The new language has funny pictures in it, though: or it used to be funny pictures. Now it's just pictures about depression." She narrows her eyes, without even the faintest thread of understanding to tug at. "Hell, maybe you should just close the door and never come back."

 "But look at all this." She gestures to the rows and rows of produce. Whole chickens and hams wrapped in plastic. People filling their carts with an abundance. "How the Res do your people make all this?"

 "It's all science," I say, grabbing a bagged salad that I'll buy to feel good about myself and probably forget in the back of the refrigerator. "It's a world that's connected everywhere. Not a square inch of land uncharted, and we've figured out exactly how to trade stuff with each other."

 "But what about wars and borders? No new land means it's a war for what's there, right?" Katiya lifts a clear carton of cotton candy-flavored grapes.

 "Please. Just wait for your world to develop the last weapon it ever will: one that can wipe an entire city off a map. One with such power that it leaves the victims as no more than shaded shadows on the wall, giving the survivors illnesses that carry from generation to generation. Then give those weapons to everyone. And then you'll understand why we don't dispute those silly lines we shake hands over," I tell her.

 I realize I've gone a little too far when we're deciding between colors of grapes. Her jaw hangs open. I get the variety pack so Katiya can take them home with her, and usher her to follow me on to the frozen meals section.

 "You seem to know a lot about war," she says. "You seem strong for your world. Did you fight?"

 "No," I say. "But my brother did."

 "Oh."

 She hesitates to ask the next question, so I answer for her when we step into the large dairy fridge, feeling the same cold he must have felt when he had the bloody holes in his abdomen.

 "But he never came back."

 "I'm sorry."

 "I just think that—" war is, but I stop myself, unwilling to go that far this soon.

 Katiya fills the space with her own words. "It must have been hard."

 "It's been hard. It was roughly five years ago. Inspired me to make something in college," I say.

 She looks down at her calloused hands, then traces the faint outline of a scar that spans from her eye down her cheek.

 I stop her before the pleasantries. "I'd rather not talk about it."

 She grasps the mesh of the cart as we walk down the frozen food aisle, maybe feeling again that I detest something about her.

 "But I need frozen stuff for work," I say, "and maybe you can get something, too. Have you tried an eggwich?"
